column7: Vol. 1 of Deep Deceptions by Miceal Ledwith. Unfortunately
column8: the plodding pace of the 57 minute DVD--as well as the ramblings of Ledwith--was very disappointing.  Ledwith brings up some great points in this DVD
column9: but never goes beyond the surface. He asserts that thinking people have discarded most of the infantile tenants of the "hamburger universe" (i.e. the "vault of the heavens" overhead with the vault of hell underneath). Yet
column10: instead of treating his audience as intelligent folk
column11: he makes nebulous comments without explaining the "what and why".  He mentions string theory (quantum physics) and the "true" nature of the big bang
column12: going on to say that levitation isn't a "miracle" but only a matter of superseding gravity with the "Torsion Field". The problem is that he's tossing about these terms in support of Jesus' words that "ye are all gods" and "greater works than these shall you do" without actually explaining the meaning or *science* of a Torsion Field and just how consciousness supersedes natural laws. (FYI: The Torsion Field is quantum spin waves of empty space. Einstein and Elie Cartan did some preliminary work on this theory in the 1920's. The Einstein-Cartan theory could possibly be used to explain ESP
column13: among other things.)  Ledwith spends a good portion of the DVD highlighting the silliness of traditional Christianity
column14: including the clouds and harps of heaven. He goes on and on about how a cloud is
column15: in reality
column16: damp and would be uncomfortable to sit on (duh) and that if one were to play the harp for eternity
column17: they'd wear down the fingers to the third knuckle. I understand highlighting the damage that traditional Christian thought has caused humanity
column18: especially in terms of evolution. In fact
column19: as a former minister trained in theology myself
column20: I probably "get it" more than most.  But while poking fun at Christian thought is popular these days
column21: you had *better* have some theological and scientific claims to back up your assertions--especially if you want to be a part of the "thinking". Christian apologists know their Bible inside and out
column22: so if Ledwith wants to undermine their fear-based
column23: illogical ideas he needs to do so with his supposed area of expertise...THEOLOGY. Heck
column24: even at a simplified level
column25: all one has to do is consider that if an individual set a paddle on fire and repeatedly hit a baby with it over and over and over
column26: this act would be considered a barbaric tragedy condemned by Christians (and others
column27: of course).   Yet
column28: God the Father would do much worse by condemning humanity to eternal torment forever and ever? Apologists would say "Well
column29: humans CHOOSE to go to hell." The interesting thing is that the Bible says "no man can come to the Father except the Holy Spirit draws him" because his understanding is "darkened".   This is just one of the many points that Ledwith could bring up
column30: but instead
column31: he preaches to the New Age choir by ridiculing monotheistic religions (primarily Christianity) via nebulous assertions. In fairness
column32: Ledwith makes excellent points
column33: but nothing that you couldn't get (much more eloquently) from Marianne Williamson
column34: Gary Zukav
column35: Eckhart Tolle
column36: Neale Donald Walsch
column37: and others. Some of these points are:  "We are pawns tossed about by those people we perceive as more capable and enlightened than us."  "If Jesus were on Earth today
column38: he wouldn't recognize his own teachings."  "Anyone who looks back at our history can only be appalled at the small-mindedness
column39: the hostility
column40: the barbarism that has characterized our whole traverse as a race."  "We don't realize how following another's image of God is spiritually and evolutionarily limiting. We don't even think of it."  "The flat earth mentality still corrupts and completely distorts our fundamental beliefs at the basic level still today."  "We've never gotten rid of the Inquistatorial mind to this day."  "The answers we've been given by religion are bizarre
column41: emotionally charged
column42: and childish."  "Heaven varies according to the broker (Christian denomination)
column43: but the basis is pretty much the same: earning credits for good behavior so you can immigrate to heaven."  "God is just a human magnified (in monotheism). We take these categories from the lowest plains of existence and impose them upon the Divine. As a result
column44: we're left with something so sentimental
column45: mawkish
column46: and inaccurate that it bears no relationship to reality."  "Whatever God is has no gender. These childish images are holding us back."  Ledwith makes other interesting comments
column47: but they beg for elaboration. One such comment is:  "(That) Jesus' death was to appease the vengeance of a savage God...this had NOTHING to do with what Jesus Christ did."  I'd love to hear his explanation of the crucifixion! Spiritual teachers such as Williamson have brilliantly explained the metaphysical aspects of the crucifixion of Christ. Does Ledwith have a clue as to why Jesus died? If he did
column48: why didn't he share it?  He quotes Jesus by saying "greater works (than I) shall you do"
column49: attempting to make the case that humans are living far below their potential--mostly due to a flat earth mentality. What he fails to mention
column50: however
column51: is that polemicists and theologians debate the meaning of "greater works" (meizona toutn in the Greek) in terms of whether "greater" refers to quantity versus quality. (My Greek professor made a case for the former
column52: saying that converts would multiply miracles by sheer numbers.)  Ledwith also perpetuates the biggest misquote circulated in New Age circles
column53: attributing "It's not our weakness that frightens us
column54: it's our power" to Nelson Mandela. The actual quote is "Our deepest fear is not that we are inadequate. Our deepest fear is that we are powerful beyond measure..."
column55: which was uttered by Marianne Williamson in her book "A Return to Love".  One of Ledwith's comments that I found particularly insightful is "As human knowledge grows
column56: the territory of God shrinks. God becomes a refugee." The "God of the gaps"
column57: as he called it
column58: are areas that we try to fill with human knowledge in the attempt to explain what we don't yet understand. An example would be ancient paganism attributing lightning to the actions of Zeus. Despite this interesting observation
column59: it's not enough to enliven the rest of the DVD.  What separates the tight
column60: insightful segements in "What the BLEEP Do We Know!?" from this DVD is that the conversations captured in BLEEP were the result of directors Chasse
column61: Arntz and Vincente ASKING probing questions of the experts...questions borne out of the directors' own curiosity and personal paths. On The Great Questions in the Hamburger Universe
column62: Vol. 1 of Deep Deceptions
column63: however
column64: Ledwith is left to ramble at the camera rather aimlessly
column65: which doesn't make for good viewing and does not offer lucid alternatives to the flat earth mentality of the hamburger universe. Perhaps this is more the fault of "director" JZ Knight.  In the end
column66: I couldn't help but feel like this DVD was thrown together in order to capitalize on BLEEP's popularity. Let's hope the subsequent installments of this series are tighter

column1: After 9/11 happened
column2: I didn't have the stomach to read (or listen to) Stupid White Men.  With the fifth anniversary of 9/11 arriving today
column3: I thought it was time to look back at how we looked before we were attacked.  I have great respect for Michael Moore and had high hopes for the book.    Alas
column4: I was very disappointed.   The book opens on its high point -- Mr. Moore's excellent characterization of how the first W. Bush "election" was stolen.  In the recounting of the "accomplishments" of the administration
column5: you'll be fascinated to know that many of the areas where spending is through the roof now were originally cut back . . . such as areas related to national security.  After that
column6: the only other good section was the one about how racism is based on false beliefs about African Americans rather than personal experience.    For the rest of the book
column7: Mr. Moore indulges in creating "solutions" that have a surface validity for someone who doesn't know anything about what he's describing.  If it were just humor
column8: I would laugh.  But the "solutions" seem to be seriously intended.  For instance
column9: the Middle East will become peaceful if Arabs learn to emulate Gandhi and use non-violent protest methods.  Really?  I wonder if he even knew that there are two groups of Muslims that are routinely waging war on one another.  In other places
column10: I think he was trying to be humorous . . . but it didn't work well enough to be funny.  For instance
column11: the book "humorously" describes the solution for creating peace in Northern Ireland as having all of the Protestants convert to Catholicism.  It just didn't seem funny.      Mr. Moore also prefers to look at every issue from an economic class point of view.  I felt like I was listening to neo-Marxism in places!  Unless you don't know how the first W. Bush election was "liberated" in Florida by Jeb Bush and his compadres
column12: you can skip this book.  You'll think more highly of Mr. Moore if you do

column1: Rather than write another review here
column2: I will instead include the letter I was compelled to write to REA when I purchased this book:  I am writing to express my deep disappointment in your Physics Subject test GRE study guide. I found its review section inconsistent and incomplete
column3: and the sample tests utterly failed to match the tone or content of the real exam itself.  As for the review section
column4: it was disappointing enough itself. Your Temperature section spends its entirety discussing the different units used to measure the property. THIS IS NOT GRE MATERIAL. If a senior year physics student cannot change between Celsius and Kelvin in his sleep
column5: I assure you
column6: he has no aspirations of continuing study in the field. Frankly
column7: he does not even have any business doing so. The rest of the Thermodynamics section suffers the same failing. The three laws of thermodynamics are the starting point for any college level thermodynamics coarse
column8: yet they close your discussion of the topic. This book fails to purvey any of the complexities of this broad
column9: interesting
column10: and very difficult field. There is no mention at all of statistical physics
column11: which is an entire branch of physics which is on the test. While this thermodynamics section was the worst part
column12: there are many problems in the rest of the book. Optics ray traces are ambiguously and inconsistently labeled. The book does a poor job of differentiating equations that are part of a derivation from those which will be encountered on the test. There is no mention of inductance in the electromagnetism section
column13: though I encountered this topic several times in actual tests (both practice and real). Impedance is also not mentioned in the circuits section. The quantum mechanics section is cut short with no mention of any of the kind of material that would be encountered in a second course
column14: such as spin
column15: angular momentum
column16: and electron transition rules. Again
column17: these are on the test.  Further
column18: your sample tests did not match up well with my experience of the actual content of the test. The GRE is not designed to be a test of student's algebra. Numerical values are very rarely given for the relevant properties in a question. As such
column19: students are tested based on knowledge of equations and unit analysis kinds of rules-of-thumb. However
column20: your sample tests included numerical substitutions in most problems
column21: and thus tested algebra abilities heavily. Students are not allowed calculators at the test
column22: so time spent on calculation is wasted. In fact
column23: I found that ability to test formulaic answer choices by unit analysis was one of the best approaches to novel or difficult problems. Had I relied heavily on your book
column24: I would not have learned this.  I'm sure I could catalogue more important subjects that were missed
column25: and find more confusing notation. Frankly
column26: though
column27: I do not have the time to waste with this book. Please realize that I understand that compiling the entire subject of physics in a single volume is a very difficult task. However
column28: in order for a book to be worthwhile for GRE preparation
column29: it must be much more complete and better organized. I consider this book a waste of my $28.95 and the valuable time I could have been studying more useful resources.  I write not to ridicule or be combative. There are not many physics GRE study guides available
column30: and a good one would be tremendously helpful to those preparing for this difficult and stressful test. The inclusion of practice tests with explained answers is a great idea. This book does have potential
column31: but it is not a good resource as of right now. It most certainly not "The Best Test Preparation for the GRE." I suggest a full review and rewrite of this book. I trust that
column32: with some work
column33: the REA can put out a study guide that is truly helpful to physics students. Please consider my encouragement to do so.  Thank you for your time

All in all this would have been a halfway decent novel if Iles---or his editor---had chopped out about 300 pages of unneccesary text.  Iles just LOVES to have two characters sit and talk for 3o

column1: Before reading this book
column2: I had no idea what Phillip Pullman's personal positions on faith and religion were and that was pretty much what this book was about -- variations on the theme of "Phillip Pullman wrote this series as a rebuttal to C.S. Lewis and Christianity".  I picked this book up because I had so enjoyed Pullman books and had found the previous "Smart Pop" series books I had read so enlightening and mentally stimulating.  Unfortunately
column3: this one did not reach that same level of interest.  I found the majority of the essays to be rather simplistic and very little of what I read made me think.  It was illuminating to hear the underlying philosophy that Pullman brought to his writing
column4: but I would have liked it if they essayists had not all addressed this same topic but had instead looked at other aspects of the book

column1: It amazes me that not a single previous reviewer noted the gaping hole in the logic of the plot that renders the entire reading excercise an utter waste of time (not mention the waste of money in purchasing the book).  The hole is this: Did the Giordano parents "look in" on Amy when they returned home from their evening out? If so
column2: and if she was asleep in bed
column3: than the suspicion of Eric would be no greater than anyone else in town. If she was missing on their return home than Eric has some major explaining to do.  Incredibly this issue was never addressed. It is beyond logic to me that neither Giordano parent would check on their 8 y.o. daughter upon  returning home from a night out.  Would you?

column4: and found the author's sources were taken from the conclusions drawn by other authors
column5: not direct sources. Many times the author gave quotes without any documentation whatsoever.  It was difficult to find additional light and knowledge on this subject when the author's bias was so plainly manifested in his writings.  It appeared that Bagley's ulterior motive was to negate the veracity of Brigham Young and the leaders of the LDS Church down to the current church President
column6: Gordon B. Hinckley.  In my opinion
column7: this book has little merit for a scholarly study. In other words
column8: let's put it this way: Juanita Brooks -- You're still Number #1!

column1: In her book
column2: Kathleen Brown offers a revision of colonial Virginia history. Relying almost entirely upon previously known and explored primary materials
column3: she constructs an argument that gender heavily influenced colonial development.        Breaking her book up chronologically into three parts
column4: Brown focuses first on England and the Virginia colony's early days. In discussing the former
column5: she establishes the role of women who adhere to social behavioral norms as that of good wives
column6: and those who do not adhere to those norms as nasty wenches. In the case of Virginia
column7: she explores the role of women in English society vis a vis Powhatan's Algonquian society. When Powhatan offered women to English settlers
column8: whether for marriage or a night's enjoyment
column9: he did so for political reasons; the settlers
column10: however
column11: thought Indians valued women less
column12: and differently
column13: than they did. Settlers further grappled with the fact that women farmed while men
column14: they thought
column15: took it easy
column16: hunting and fishing.        The second part focuses on the change in roles of women
column17: and the corresponding change in how men though of them. As Virginia became more permanent
column18: and as slaves became more prevalent
column19: "good wives" came to mean the elite women
column20: whereas "nasty wenches" meant servant or non-elite women. Following Bacon's Rebellion
column21: this labeling shifted somewhat as elite men attempted to break the unofficial alliance between black slaves and white servants. Principally
column22: the violations of white women that formerly would have made them nasty wenches now were less serious
column23: while those same violations of black women were more so.        The last part explores the domination of men and the lives of elite women. Men became much more patriarchal
column24: establishing social norms and laws to that effect. They were "anxious" in the sense that they were now required to hold domination over their wives
column25: families
column26: and farms
column27: and maintain strict adherence to those norms and laws. Relying heavily on the writings of William Byrd II and Landon Carter
column28: Brown points out the fears these men had of declining virility
column29: disobedient sons
column30: and the like. Women
column31: meanwhile
column32: came together against their husbands
column33: quietly undermining them on occasions
column34: especially in discipline issues
column35: and generally developing a women's society of tea parties and such.        On the one hand
column36: Brown's revisionist attempt is a worthwhile endeavor; only the foolish would say women had no role or impact whatsoever in colonial development. As historians have largely ignored or downplayed this role
column37: her study is therefore relevant. On the other hand
column38: she delves far too deeply into the sex lives of leading men. Her study was not one solely of the role of gender
column39: but also of sexuality. To a certain and very limited extent that exploration is worthwhile-certainly the colonists were concerned with fornication
column40: bastardy and the like-but do I
column41: the reader
column42: really need to know on which days Byrd gave his wife a "flourish
column43: and whether or not he was vigorous"? No. Furthermore
column44: certain inherent flaws exist in a reinterpretation that relies heavily on modern and liberal views of sex and sexuality. Consequently
column45: there are certain aspects of the book that are worth reading
column46: but one should select those aspects carefully.

column1: Have you ever watched a movie or TV program that started out badly
column2: but you kept watching in the faint hope that it would eventually get better as it went along
column3: but it never did?  Alexander and Seidman's "Culture and Society: Contemporary Debates" left me with precisely that feeling.  A bit of context: I teach an undergraduate interdisciplinary course
column4: and I am looking for a new textbook that students could use.  I selected this book because of its advertised content as well as the inclusion of some seminal thinkers in the field of sociology -- Saussure
column5: Geertz
column6: and Foucault
column7: to name a few.  However
column8: this book -- published in 1990 -- is a collection of 31 short articles (culled from texts and journals) that were already 5 to 15 years old at the time of publication and apparently have not been updated since then.  The book is broken down into two sections: "Analytical debates: Understanding the relative autonomy of culture" and "Substantive debates: Moral order and social crisis - perspectives on modern culture."  In each section there are various subsections (e.g.
column9: "Marxian approaches to culture
column10: Modernism or postmodernism: Dissolution or reconstruction of moral order?"
column11: each with two or three articles addressing the theme.  However
column12: the target audience is academe and not the layperson
column13: given the impenetrable prose and countless references to other authors and social theories.  A few excerpts may serve as examples of the level of complexity.  "I define postmodern as incredulity toward metanarratives" (Lyotard
column15: p. 330).  "Introjection implies the existence of an inner dimension distinguished from and even antagonistic to the external exigencies -- and individual consciousness and an individual unconscious[ness] apart from public opinion and behavior (Marcuse
column17: pp. 287-88).  "The danger of academism is obviously inherent in any rationalized teaching which tends to mint
column18: within one doctrinal body
column19: precepts
column20: prescriptions
column21: and formulae
column22: explicitly described and taught
column23: more often negative than positive
column24: which a traditional education imparts in the form of a habitus
column25: directly apprehended uno intuito
column26: as a global style not susceptible to analytical breakdown" (Bordieu
column28: p. 208).  If these three quotes resonate with your understanding of culture and society
column29: then this is the book for you!  There are a few bright spots in this book.  Robert Bellah's entry on "Civil religion in America" is well worth a look in light of recent developments.  Marshall Sahlins' "Food as Symbolic Code" is another interesting consideration of a topic we take for granted.  However
column30: a reader who is looking for cross-cultural analysis and discussion of contemprary debates in society would be hard-pressed to find many answers while wading through all 370 pages of this theoretical text

column1: So this is the fate of rock and roll packaged in one album -  hipsters for hip's sake. It will be interesting to see if these guys ever make a mark again. If you ask me
column2: the gimicks are pretty much exhausted and crashed into the ground after about the fifth song or so. I mean we got it - we are no longer so innocent about the mediums of art and communication as being something transparent and autonomous - the avenues of expression have been pressed to the limits.  So now we revert to 'meta-music'! If we can't be progressive or effective we can still be hip. I think the crucial moment in the album for me was during the second listen of 'my little brother' where the singer/talker says something like 'all we ever wanted was for our parents to worry about us.' Isn't this kind of like a self-critique of the whole Art Brut project/aesthetic? As if rock and roll never functions for political/social purposes but instead only functions in service of narcissistic self-defense in the context of bourgouis familial dramas. As for the whole 'hipster' craze - yes - rock and roll does work in the service of bourgeois narcissism.  However
column3: when out of the hands of hipsters
column4: is this the case of 'rock music'? That
column5: I think
column6: is yet to be determined and has defintely been proven otherwise in its past history

column1: Alan Dean Foster's The Approaching Storm is his third entry in the Star Wars universe
column2: but his first in the modern era of EU. He was the ghostwriter for the novelization of A New Hope (credited to George Lucas) and also wrote the vintage Splinter of the Mind's Eye
column3: one of the handful of novels from the days of the original trilogy. The book's front jacket proclaims "An exciting prologue to Star Wars: Attack of the Clones
column4: while the back mentions two Jedi and their apprentices fighting impossible odds" while "the entire galaxy watches and waits."   Unfortunately
column5: I must charge the dust jacket with over-hyping the scope of this tale. Though the book tries hard to convince us that Ansion is critical to preventing the breakaway of many systems to the Separatists
column6: the story itself just feels too leisurely and the planet too insignificant to carry this weight. Essentially the two Jedi and their apprentices take a long field trip to find some nomads out in the plains of Ansion and convince them to make peace with the city folk
column7: thereby ensuring Ansion's continued loyalty to the Republic. The aspect of this I found most frustrating? After reading in extreme detail about their journey there
column8: Foster totally glosses over the actual negotiations between the two most powerful nomad factions facilitated by the Jedi - there's no payoff! One minute they're about to go to war
column9: the next they've sat down and rapidly become old friends.   I also found the writing to be curiously stilted. Star Wars is certainly not noted for snappy dialogue
column10: but most of the conversations in here don't even read fluidly on the page
column11: let alone if they are read aloud. Like Rogue Planet
column12: this book seemed rather like a non-Star Wars science fiction tale re-skinned with Star Wars trappings and published as such.   Despite the book promising more
column13: I did enjoy seeing the Jedi on a small-scale
column14: personal mission. There aren't many books dealing with Obi-Wan and Anakin's relationship pre-Clone Wars
column15: so it's good to see that explored. Since the book is set immediately before Attack of the Clones
column16: their dynamic is very similar to what we see in the film. Visually
column17: Luminara Unduli and Barriss Offee are a terrific pair
column18: and it's fun to see their personalities fleshed out. Separatist scheming is always welcomed as well
column19: and I have a weakness for Hutts as characters: Soergg's repartee with Barriss in the climax was easy to visualize and quite entertaining. Also
column20: the creatures of Ansion were diverse and well-realized and the planet itself vividly described.   I would have liked to see more from The Approaching Storm; I love Attack of the Clones and was very excited to read a book setting up the events of the film. While it's a fleetingly cool feeling to know all the details of the "mission to Ansion" Mace Windu mentions early in the film
column21: I think this book missed an opportunity to try for something more.

column1: After many years
column2: I decided to finally give Kathy Reichs' Temperance Brennan series a go.  So
column3: where better to start than her debut novel 'Deja Dead' which introduces Reichs' heroine.  Temperance Brennan is an American forensic anthropologist working in Montreal for what I'm guessing is the French-Canadian equivalent of a Medical Examiner's office.  Of course our heroine is head strong
column4: independent
column5: and unlucky in love (aren't they all?).  Well
column6: some murders start turning up and
column7: amazingly enough
column8: our intrepid anthropologist is the only person that links the crimes together.  Do the police believe her?  No
column9: so she must investigate the crimes on her own.  And by doing so
column10: the murderer then turns his attention to Brennan and her family and friends (don't all killers eventually do that?).  First off
column11: the book is bloated.  The book (at least the paperback version) clocks in at about 530 pages.  Reichs' writes too much about menial tasks that her character
column12: Brennan
column13: does during her usual day.  Does anyone really want to hear repeatedly about what a character had for dinner or what paperwork she does at work?  I know I don't want to read it.  Now I'm a person who enjoys a nice
column14: long book but 'Deja Dead' (where did she get that title anyway?) is about two hundred pages too long.  And it is a very slow read.    Secondly
column15: her main character
column16: Brennan
column17: just isn't likeable.  In fact
column18: I found her quite annoying.  The policemen in the novel are portrayed as incompetent
column19: arrogant jerks who are too worried about being right than they are about doing the right thing.  When in fact I think that they just didn't want to deal with this overly nosy anthropologist who is obviously stepping on toes and irritating people who are just trying to do their jobs.  Reichs' tries to portray Brennan as a lone crusader fighting against all these odds to get to the criminal.  When in fact she is an irritating anthropologist who has no business investigating a murder.  She is
column20: basically
column21: a laboratory-based employee who should not be in the field.  So I don't blame the cops in the book that don't like her.  She's butting her nose in where it doesn't belong and
column22: in a part I actually liked

column1: I was excited to see what all the fuss was about after hearing about kettlebells and what an effective training tool they are.  However
column2: after  reading this book it was evident that it is incomplete and poorly conceived
column3: of poor quality and lacking in too many areas to be taken seriously.  (Also
column4: it has since been superceded by "Enter the Kettlebell" in which Pavel contradicts himself.)  I was confused by the many typographical errors with whole paragraphs being repeated out of sequence in non-related chapters and the lack of photographs required to do a good job of conveying how to properly execute the various movements.  This could be quite dangerous for the trainee who doesn't have the time
column5: money or inclination to spend $1500-2000 to take a beginners kettlebell course.  Surely this must be a Russian plot to bilk hard-working Americans out of their money and send them on a mission of useless training programs?  I got the distinct impression that Pavel's books are written in serial fashion to either 1) convince you that you MUST take a "certified" kettlebell course or (2) get you to buy more expensive books or (3)get you to buy expensive DVD's.  "Take down that wall Gorby"...so those wacky Russians can experience the American dream by selling over-hyped books supposedly containing valuable Russian training "secrets".  As much as the kettlebell "cultists" would like you to believe how great they are
column6: fortunately most of us are not confined to a Russian gulag or currently in exile in Siberia working out with balls of iron with a handle in the sub-freezing cold
column7: performaing boring
column8: mind numbing endless repetitions of snatches and swings.  No
column9: here in America
column10: a long time ago
column11: someone came up with the idea of ADJUSTABLE dumbells and barbells with which you can progressively add weight and thereby grow in strength and muscularity.  Plenty of trainees around the world have built great physiques and strength without ever having touched a kettlebell.  Keep that in mind and try to see past the hype

I have now seen two Judy Garland movies -- The Wizard of Oz and this one. All bets are off about a third.  I Could Go On Singing has the morbid distinction of being Judy's final film. She plays -- get this -- a world famous tough-talking yet vulnerable vocalist with a tormented personal life and an appetite for prescription medication and martinis. Quite a stretch.   Overall
column2: this movie is a confused hybrid of a melodramatic soap opera
column3: a London travelogue
column4: and a "live" Judy Garland stage performance. It will probably be filed under "Musicals" at your video store
column5: but that's not really accurate -- nobody spontaneously breaks out into Wizard of Oz-style song and dance production numbers. Instead
column6: the tunes are performed by Judy's alter-ego "character" Jenny Bowman at pseudo-live sold out (of course) solo shows at the London Palladium. She sings a handful of oddly forgettable and unremarkable showstoppers
column7: including the title song which features unfortunate lyrics such as these:   I could go on singing
column8: til the cows come home And the rooster starts to crow
column9: crow
column10: crow When I see your eyes
column11: I go all out I must vocalize til you shout "enough already!" I could go on singing
column12: til the moon turns pink Anything from Faust to  Ink-a-dink-a-dink!  Not even Judy can manage to deliver this stuff convincingly

column14: "It Never Was You" by Kurt Weill

column16: especially the zippy "Helicopter Ride" symphony and the experimental
column17: Ives-ian "Matt's Dilemma" interlude. And you get to see Judy's son (Matt -- the dilemma being he doesn't yet know he's Judy's son) performing Gilbert and Sullivan in drag
column18: if that's the kind of thing you're into.  Otherwise

column1: I am grateful that this conversation has begun
column2: but this book is by no means the final word on the subject.    I found 200 pages of individual acts of backstabbing to be uninsightful.  We already know women can be vicious.  While this book takes heroic steps to sympathetically rationalize treachery and dispel the "good girl-bad girl" dichotomy
column3: it would be a far more inspirational read if it gave practical advice for dealing with our inevitable day to day confrontations.    I was hoping this book would lay out the nuances and pitfalls of working with women before dispensing some apt suggestions for diffusing tense situations.  Perhaps with some humorous/memorable examples of these tactics applied.  I was disappointed.    I had to glean from the anecdotes the sorts of environmental conditions which could lead to thinly veiled hostility: feeling threatened by youth
column4: talent
column5: beauty
column6: race
column7: social class or contested token woman status.  Should I find myself in possession of one of these threatening advantages
column8: I'm unsure how to react outside of warily paranoid.    Although this book alludes to individual advocacy
column9: at its core it is a collective action cop-out.  Women are reluctant to make individual changes because their less altruistic coworkers will take advantage of them.  The solution?  Macro-level reform meted out by our government
column10: media and employers.    Amidst a slew of gratuitous quotes
column11: it seems Margaret Mead's critical message has been left out: "Never doubt that a small group of thoughtful
column12: committed people can change the world. Indeed
column13: it is the only thing that ever has."

This book is not a serious or scholarly piece of work
column2: and I recommend that you not waste your time reading it.  It begins with a description of the life of Mohammed
column3: the origins and spread of Islam
column4: and the creation of various Islamic sects.  This is probably the best part of the book
column5: but it is still very poor.  For example
column6: Schwartz never really explains even the basic distinction between Shi'a and Sunni Islam.  And Schwartz's overall goals badly tarnish his discussion:  He wants to portray traditional Islam as being perfectly pluralist
column7: tolerant
column8: and peace-loving
column9: so as to contrast it with hate-filled
column10: intolerant
column11: and violent Wahhabism.  As a result
column12: his description of the Ottoman Empire (representing Schwartz's traditional Islam) is completely uncritical and consequently not credible.  For instance
column13: he never even mentions the Ottomans' barbaric and murderous treatment of Armenians and Kurds
column14: to name just two salient examples.  The rest of the book follows a similar pattern:  There are Muslims Schwartz likes (especially Sufis)
column15: and there are Muslims he hates (Wahhabis
column16: plus others who are not Wahhabis but whom Schwartz describes as "Wahhabized
column17: though he never explains what  that's supposed to mean).  The good" Muslims can do no wrong
column18: and the "bad" Muslims are behind just about every act of terrorism committed anywhere on the globe.  I know this sounds like it must be a charicature of the book
column19: but it's not.  Rather
column20: Schwartz's book is itself a charicature of the complexity of contemporary international affairs.  An example will illustrate Schwartz's appalling sloppiness with evidence.  On pages 217-218
column21: he claims that a "manifesto" written by Osama bin Laden proves that Saddam Hussein is connected with bin Laden and Al Qaeda.  I found this surprising
column22: because there is
column23: to my knowledge
column24: no proven link between them whatsoever (and I have followed this issue very closely).  In fact
column25: it is well known that bin Laden has always hated Hussein and secular rulers like him
column26: that bin Laden had called for Hussein's overthrow
column27: that Hussein hated bin Laden and had brutally repressed Islamic fundamentalists like him
column28: etc.  (See
column29: for example
column30: the analysis of this issue in a report by the Carnegie Endownment for International Peace).  So I was very curious to see what evidence Schwartz had found in bin Laden's "manifesto" to support his conclusion that
column31: in spite of all that
column32: Hussein and bin Laden were allies.  Here is Schwartz's evidence:  In his "manifesto
column33: bin Laden (1) called for an end to the UN sanctions on Iraq, (2) lamented the destruction inflicted on Iraq in the first Gulf War, and (3) also lamented the deaths of Iraqi children that were caused by the UN santions.  I'm not kidding--that is the sum total of Schwartz's proof" that Hussein was an ally of bin Laden and Al Qaeda in their global terror campaign.  It's absurd.  The book does contain one interesting thesis:  Schwartz claims that for most Americans
column34: the face of violent and dangerous Islamic extremism is Ayatolla Khomeini and the Iranian revolution
column35: while Americans have regarded Saudi Islam as "moderate" because the Saudis are US allies.  Schwartz plausibly argues that the reverse is true:  Saudi Islam (Wahhabism) is much more dangerous because of its support for a "holy war" without borders
column36: while the Islamic revolution in Iran was really about liberating the Shi'a of Iran from oppression under the Shah
column37: not about waging a larger war beyond Iran (although Schwartz does acknowledge Iranian support for certain Palestinian militant groups).  The thesis is interesting and possibly true.  But that one interesting point certainly doesn't make this dreadful book worth reading.  If you are looking for an introduction to Islam
column38: or for insightful and well-reasoned discussion of world affairs
column39: please look elsewhere

I read this book in college
column2: not as part of a course
column3: but out of curiousity because it was the favorite whipping boy of many of my peers and professors.  After reading it
column4: I understood why.  The effect of this book
column5: intended or not
column6: is to preserve the reverence for the outdated "Western canon".  Ultimately
column7: I found the book self-serving in the extreme
column8: as it secures Hirsh's place in academia
column9: if it is believed.  I admit that reading the list of items Hirsch thinks we should know and trying to place them is an amusing parlor game.  However
column10: one should not draw conclusions about one's self worth from success or failure at this game.  The list itself is deeply flawed for more than one reason.  First
column11: it is heavily weighted towards the knowledge of old college professors
column12: not young college professors
column13: and certainly not college students.  Second
column14: it is heavily weighted by Hirsch's Anglophilia.  Third
column15: although it does not purport to be exhastive
column16: the danger of any list
column17: and this one is no exception
column18: is that it will be taken as exhaustive by the lazy reader.  Finally
column19: Hirsch's argument that his concept of cultural literacy is finally pragmatic and not philosophical in that it lays the groundwork of "common experience" for students and teachers is particularly narrow.  Hirsch must have been wearing cultural blinders when he wrote this not to see that much of the common experience that people draw on today is formed not by the Academy
column20: but by popular culture.  Hirsch's argument breaks down here because he tries to force the popular culture of a different age upon the public so that they will have a common experience with him
column21: instead of exposing himself current pop culture simply because it doesn't meet his narrow aesthetic criteria.  If you read this book
column22: read it as a cautionary tale about trying to quantify any concept so nebulous as "cultural literacy."  Interrogate the precepts of this book by trying to have a converstaion about Buffy the Vampire Slayer and its relationship to religion among American teenagers with any of your "old guard" religion or philosophy professors. I think there may be a hint of jealousy in this book.  I've often thought of Zizek as the kind of guy who strives to be the rock star of philosophy. Of course
column2: more than ten years after his death
column3: Deleuze is packing more philosophical arenas than Zizek ever will.  This is because
column4: in my humble opinion
column5: Zizek is and always will be a second rate philosopher.  He is the Douglas Coupland of academic philosophy in that
column6: while he is often an interesting read
column7: one always walks away from the book feeling like they've gained nothing but a few perverse ways of stating the obvious.  I will admit
column8: Zizek has a flare for writing
column9: notably
column10: I think in the Ticklish Subject and Welcome to the Desert of the Real.  But this book not only failed to accomplish it's goals but it did so rather uninterestingly.  Somewhere around the end of the first third of the book he quotes Deleuze's famous passage about buggering other philosophers in the behind.  I've always loved the passage and til that point I thought the book was heating up so I had hopes of engaging in an eye-opening debate about Deleuze with both the text and my own preconceptions.  But what I got from that point on was a stream of endless
column11: pretentious comparisions between what most people assume Hegel meant and what Zizek somehow interprets Deleuze to mean.    Basically
column12: it seemed to me like Zizek's project was misguided in that it relied too heavily on a limited interpretation of Deleuze based on Zizek's slight admiration for the Logic of Sense and his disdain for Deleuze's work with Guattari.  Zizek almost comes off as a crying child who wanted ice cream when everyone else wanted cake and couldn't have his way.  He passes over without even the slightest mention the idea that perhaps A Thousand Plateau's truly is a revolutionary text (or radical series of texts - whatever).  He does this because he likes better the ideas he has developed out of the Logic of Sense.    In other words
column13: Zizek is fatalistically attached to the offspring that emerged when Deleuze's logic of sense poked him in the butt.  The joke's on you

column1: I wanted to like this book.  I love Sagas of Icelanders.  I was ecstatic over the Poetic Edda.  Snorri's "Prose Edda" was frequently mentioned in my other reading
column2: and I decided I would have to check it out.  What a disappointment. I must clarify that by saying that the Prose Edda is an EXTREMELY important book of immense value to students of Medeival literature (specifically Scandinavian / Norse / Icelandic.)  It is the single most complete record of  Norse mythology which we have today
column3: and along with the Poetic Edda
column4: constitutes practically the sole source of material for all books which re-tell the mythological stories.  But the Edda is
column5: unfortunately
column6: a book to be read only for the value of the information it contains; not for entertainment.  All of the interesting material in the Edda is re-told (in much more readable ways) elsewhere.  Snorri himself
column7: in the course of this book
column8: re-tells "Voluspa" (from the Poetic Edda) and gives a brief synopsis of the Volsunga Saga. Edda was written as a handbook for poets and scholars
column9: to aid in understanding ancient Scandinavian poetry
column10: which was thick with mythological allusions. Edda also provides guidelines for composing new poems using traditional forms.  It was written two or three centuries into the Christian era of northern Europe
column11: when old pagan lore was already nearly forgotten.  Snorri's book kept his ancestor's cultural heritage from disappearing completely.  He treats the old myths very kindly
column12: but is careful to throw in the obligatory Christian warnings about "false religion."  According to "Gylfaginning
column13: (the first and most interesting part of the Edda) the Norse gods - the Aesir - were originally a tribe of people who migrated to the North from Turkey.  They were veterans of the Trojan War (!) so cultured and technologically advanced that they were regarded as gods by the ignorant folk in the lands they conquered and settled.  According to Snorri, most of the mythological stories are analogous to episodes from the Iliad. The second section of the Edda is called Skaldskaparmal" and it is very tedious.  It consists of a mythological discussion between Aegir (the sea god) and Bragi (the god of poetry) in which Bragi explains various kinds of kennings.  A kenning is a poetic figure of speech in which a person or object is referred to by describing it in terms of another person or object.  Then that secondary person or object can be referred to by yet another substitute
column14: down to 4 or 5 levels of circumlocution
column15: all of which has to be figured out by the listener to determine exactly what the poet is talking about.  Kennings are like riddles
column16: allegories
column17: metaphors
column18: and allusions rolled all into one.  A fairly detailed myhtological background is required to make sense of them - thus
column19: the reason for the Edda.  A few stories are told which explain some kennings
column20: but gradually Snorri loses track of the "conversation" that initially provided structure for this section
column21: and the reader gets mired amidst interminable lists of poetic synonyms for swords
column22: ships
column23: gold
column24: and so on.  Quotes from old poems illustrate the use of many of the kennings. The translator - for reasons which are certainly valid - opted to render all of the verse as prose
column25: preserving its literal meaning [with allegorical meanings choppily inserted in square brackets
column26: ] but utterly detroying its power as POETRY. The final section is called "Hattatal" and it consists of a few verse quotations and three original poems composed by Snorri himself in a different style for each verse
column27: with sections of prose in between stanzas to explain the technical details (rhyme
column28: meter
column29: alliteration
column30: etc) of each style.  There's a total of 102 verses in the Hattatal
column31: and the poetry here is actually somewhat interesting; more so
column32: at least
column33: than the nuts-and-bolts discussion of the fine points of skaldic composition.  In this section
column34: each verse is presented in the original Old Icelandic (with modernized spelling) with English translation underneath. At the end of this volume
column35: the translator has provided a handy eight-page summary that will tell you what you missed and/or forgot as you slogged in a bleary-eyed daze through Skaldskaparmal and Hattatal.  There's also an alphabetical index of names so you can look up things and use the Edda for what it was intended to be: a reference book. I'm glad I read it
column36: I guess
column37: since I am pretty "into" this kind of thing ... but I wouldn't recommend it for anyone who is just curious about Norse mythology.  Sure
column38: this book is "the Source" but you'll have more fun reading one of the dozens of more recent re-tellings

In 1872 Charles Darwin's "The Expression of Emotions in Man and Animals" addressed how emotions were an evolutionary adaptative process of the human species. In that book and in other similar books since (e.g.
column2: Johnston's "Why We Feel: The Science of Human Emotions
column3: 1999), evolutionary biologists have shown that the adaptative function of emotions is to get us moving very quickly without having to rationalize or think about imminent perils as we had to do in our earlier hunter-gather society. In 1995, Daniel Goleman in his pioneering book Emotional Intelligence" brought many of these evolutionary and scientific ideas to the attention of modern readers
column4: advocating much greater attention be paid to developing healthy emotions in all of us
column5: beginning in grade school and in the home. Now
column6: Goleman returns in a book that highlights a symposia consisting of philosophers
column7: psychologists
column8: doctors
column9: and the Dali Lama to see what insights Eastern thought in general
column10: and Tibetan Buddhism in particular
column11: might glean for us. The effort
column12: while noble
column13: has very little to recommend it.  Most of the book tangentially describes the goings on of the symposium itself; hardly electrifying knowledge! The rest of the book tries to correlate (where possible) Eastern Buddhist thought about emotions with the modern Western scientific paradigm. Often
column14: this is no more than using Tibetan language for English terms. The neo-Darwinian prototype is occasionally raised
column15: but never fully addressed. Then
column16: in a systematic fashion
column17: the emotions
column18: affects
column19: afflictions
column20: emotional balance
column21: etc.
column22: are described in a metaphysical context of how the Dali Lama and other lamas regard Western insights. Some spiritualists
column23: transcendentalists
column24: Eastern philosophers
column25: and religionists may find the Dali Lama's comments insightful
column26: but I found them bordering on the naive and over simplistic. Don't we already know (in the West
column27: at least) that some emotions are healthy while others are simply inappropriate? It doesn't require new semantics in old wineskins to show us what we already know.   There's no question that some of the emotions we've developed over epochs of evolution no longer serve our modern-day purposes (although this isn't even explored). Further
column28: there's no question that some people have either excessive or deficient emotions that could benefit from a reappraisal and some reeducation. For example
column29: while anger in some people may precipitate compassion for the injured or harmed (a good effect)
column30: others blow off steam with weapons
column31: familial abuse
column32: and inappropriate agitation (bad effect). So
column33: what's new about this insight? Nothing. Goleman does devote a chapter to writing about "schooling" the good effects from bad
column34: but I found the reeducation slender and lanky (e.g.
column35: "our secular goal should be to support a healthy emotional immune system"). The analogy and metaphor are quaint
column36: but not very descriptive or prescriptive of the reeducation program.  Emotions
column37: according to most scientists as opposed to the doctrinaire religionists
column38: are generally regarded as a normal and healthy part of our intrinsic human nature (see Johnston
column39: supra.
column40: Pinker
column41: "How the Mind Works
column42: Wright, The Moral Animal
column43: Ridley, Origins of Virtue
column44: Sober & Wilson, Unto Others
column45: et alia). For those who suffer from inappropriate emotions, and obviously many people do, there are excellent self-help books (e.g., Cohen, What Would Aristotle Do?" Ellis
column46: "A Guide to Rational Living
column47: Nussbaum, Therapy of Desire
column48: Burns, Feeling Good
column49:
et alia). Reading the signposts from Eastern philosophy does little to inform us either about our emotions or how to control the inappropriate ones. Giving Western concepts Tibetan names does little to nothing to edify. Unlike Goleman's earlier book, this book not recommended

 O'Reilly is looking out for the elite interests who pay him and give him a platform.  He certainly isn't looking out for the general public.  In fact, he regularly attacks the civic organizations that the American people have created like the ACLU (which protected Limbaugh's medical privacy), the NAACP, unions, the National Organization of Women, and many other groups and individuals who are doing all sorts of worthwhile work. I feel sorry for those who are so isolated and intellectually impoverished that they take O'Reilly seriously.  If people need help to think through O'Reilly's brand of elite propaganda, they can check out DVDs like The Corporation" and "Manufacturing Consent: Noam Chomsky and the Media." See also good radio shows like Democracy Now!

Be very patient...." almost begging the audience not to walk out while she's singing solo.  It's almost as if she knows that the audience will have to suffer her solo attempts until the "friends" arrive.  The irony is that Sheryl solo is the best part of the album.   With the others on board

column6: Stevie Nicks

column8: Chrissie Hynde and by including so many rock gods she herself is diminished in importance and stature.  Her songs "It Don't Hurt" and "There Goes the Neighborhood" stand out on the album showing that Sheryl can rock harder and better than any of her "friends." Too bad she didn't include "Am I Getting Through" -- the Part 2 of that was a great rock moment.  Natalie Maines' grating voice (like fingernails on a chalkboard) completely ruin "Strong Enough."  Chrissie sounds like a zombie on "If It Makes You Happy"

column1: It's true that a woman's general health may play a role in her fertility (and certainly in her ability to carry a healthy pregnancy)
column2: and that certain medical problems can drastically increase the risk of infertility (untreated polycystic ovary syndrome
column3: STDs).  This book might be useful in suggesting some testing that women in their early 30s might do to help them decide how long it might be relatively safe to delay trying to conceive.  But this book also contains some of the same hype that makes women mistakenly confident that they can easily get pregnant with their own eggs after age 40 (or even 45!):  "You can have it all. A challenging career. A satisfying personal life. A loving mate. And a baby when you're ready." (back cover)  "In addition to the women's revolution and the technological boom weighing in on the age of childbearing
column4: it's become downright fashionable to be a mature mom. Our superstars are looking more capable and beautiful than ever with a baby in tow
column5: including Geena Davis (first-time mom at age 46)
column6: Madonna (second-time mom at 41)
column7: Kim Basinger (gave birth at 44)
column8: and Susan Sarandon (who had babies at 39
column10: and 45). Former *cover* girls are now focused on their *baby* girls (and boys) including over-40 moms Christie Brinkley
column11: Iman
column12: and Cheryl Tiegs (mother of twins at 52 who used a surrogate to carry the babies
column13: although the eggs were her own)." (pp 4-5)  It's true that most women can get PREGNANT and GIVE BIRTH in their 40s
column14: but what this isn't telling you is that a very significant percentage cannot get pregnant with their own eggs in their 40s
column15: and a majority cannot get pregnant with their own eggs in their late 40s.  If a woman is happy to go through several cycles of in vitro fertilization
column16: spend tens of thousands of dollars for the medical procedures and the egg donor
column17: and become pregnant with the genetic baby of another woman (as most of the celebrities mentioned above did)
column18: then yes
column19: medical technology has much to offer - and that's wonderful! I don't at all mean to suggest anything negative about this way to become a mother.  But many women reading the tabloids and this book may not understand that that route (or adoption) is the route that they very well may HAVE to take if they delay childbearing until their 40s or perhaps even to their late 30s.  As a woman who didn't find my husband and marry until age 35
column20: I understand well that there are plenty of weighty reasons not to have children younger
column21: and I'm all in favor of options.  But I hope women's decisions will be informed ones.  This book is a mixed bag when it comes to helping women be informed

column1: Do we really need another Mencken biography
column2: especially one as disparaging as Terry Teachout's?  Mencken haters already have Kemler's viewpoint and Angoff's discredited account (Teachout draws from both).  The rest of us can choose from the more detailed versions of Goldberg
column3: Bode
column4: Manchester and Hobson
column5: though Mencken's autobiographical works are preferable.       Why does Teachout wish to discredit Mencken?  Is he another government or religious sycophant?  Could this otherwise obscure journalist be jealous of Mencken's talent
column6: fame
column7: accomplishments and free speech?  Does Mencken's dismissal of his precious Henry James rankle?  Won't his publisher accept accuracy?  Perhaps the reason is buried in the "About the Author" page at the book's end:  Teachout is a jazz musician
column8: and Mencken hated jazz.  If Teachout also likes disco
column9: I sure don't want him writing my bio (not that I rate one).  Since Teachout doubtless considers his book's title derisive
column10: let's return the favor and dub him The Virtuoso.       "The Skeptic" is more subjective commentary than biography.  Ideally
column11: a biographer should stick to the facts; bias
column12: in either direction
column13: belongs on the op-ed page.  The Virtuoso faults another Mencken biographer for trying to copy Mencken's style
column14: yet he falls into the same trap.  He also copies from his own introduction to A Second Mencken Chrestomathy.  Several typos betray a poor job of proofreading.  Little new is added; most of the Mencken quotes can be found elsewhere.  While reading it
column15: I kept stopping to consult Mencken's far superior writing.  I never felt like I was actually there.       Rather than choose a defining moment in Mencken's career
column16: such as his coverage of the Scopes trial or his agreement to review books for The Smart Set
column17: The Virtuoso begins his meandering prologue with the 1934 Gridiron Club speeches that he claims sparked Mencken's lasting hatred of FDR.  Mencken wrote against Roosevelt II since at least 1920; after FDR became president
column18: Mencken waited until Prohibition ended before attacking the New Deal.  Perhaps Mencken wrote more about FDR because he was president for so long
column19: but he had a valid point
column20: since Roosevelt II was as close to a dictator as America came until Bush II stole the election.  Besides
column21: Mencken was at least as hard on Hoover
column22: Coolidge
column23: Harding
column24: and Wilson.       The Virtuoso wonders why Mencken could write "I am thus inclined to believe that the world is constantly growing better
column25: at least on its more enlightened levels....Every time the scientists take another fort from the theologians and politicians there is genuine human progress" during World War II.  Should we examine his own commentary during the Iraq wars?  He also claims
column26: "Mencken failed to grasp the full extent of Nazi Germany's depravity".  As early as May 12
column28: Mencken wrote in a private letter
column29: "...by talking and acting in a completely lunatic manner
column30: Hitler and his associates have thrown away the German case and given the enemies of their country enough ammunition to last for years."  He later wrote
column31: "I dislike all of Hitler's ideas save one
column32: and that is the idea that England should keep out of Central Europe."       The Virtuoso claims that Mencken wrote no more fiction after 1904
column33: completely ignoring A Book of Burlesques
column34: published more than 10 years later.  He calls Clarence Darrow an atheist; Darrow was an agnostic.  He quotes Mencken's conclusion that "journalism is not an exact science":  neither
column35: apparently
column36: is biography
column37: when conducted by today's journalists.       Mencken's inconsistencies bother The Virtuoso.  He notes that Mencken had -- and met -- tight deadlines during his Smart Set years
column38: then complains that Mencken's writings lack depth.  How
column39: exactly
column40: is that consistent?  Among his various categorizations
column41: The Virtuoso accurately calls Mencken a contrarian
column42: though only once.  Had he followed up on this description
column43: perhaps he'd have found some consistency.       The Virtuoso plays only the tunes that he wants us to hear; one of his favorites is anti-Semetism.  Mencken spared no ethnic groups; he even insulted Germans and the English
column44: despite being 3/4 German and 1/4 English.  His most vicious diatribes were against hillbillies
column45: yet no one objects to that.  Why is deriding Jews forbidden while hillbillies are fair game?  If The Virtuoso wants consistency.....       Both sides generally agree that Mencken's political forecasts were right about half of the time; The Virtuoso allows Mencken only a few accuracies.  One that he missed was Mencken's prediction of Bush II's presidency in the July 26
column46: 1920 Baltimore Evening Sun:  "On some great and glorious day the plain folks of the land will reach their heart's desire at last
column47: and the White House will be adorned by a downright moron."  Step aside
column48: Nostradamus.       Mencken's lasting values
column49: among others
column50: are that he thought outside of the mainstream
column51: and his often timeless writings are a major archive of the 20th Century's first half.  Whether friendly or hostile
column52: no biography can compare.

column1: Jean should have stayed dead.  If you read the original stories after she became Phoenix there were many things that she still did as Jean Grey that meant a great deal.  Her and Wolverine had an odd relationship together as he grew to love her and she grew closer to Scott (Cyclops).  She formed a psionic rapport with Scott where they could keep in constant touch and share their love for one another.  They had adventures and the newer team members (at the time) became closer to Jean and fought side by side with her.  She sacrificed herself in issue #137 of the Uncanny X-Men and the readers really felt an emotional loss.  She had been someone we and the new X-Men came to know and care about.  The whole Phoenix Rising storyline and Jean coming back just cheated everyone of that investment in her character.  It wasn't really her that we were caring for and blah blah blah.  That's a bunch of crap because some of those stories from issue #101 (1st Phoenix) to issue #137 (death of Phoenix) were the best in Marvel history.  Jean
column2: the person
column3: was a big part of those stories and saying that it was not really her is just the biggest farce that a comic series has ever pulled.  I know that a lot of characters die and then come back but her death was so well done and played out and led to many other things (Scott leaving
column4: team remorse
column5: etc...) that bringing her back just really left me feeling cheated.  Basically it means Wolverine didn't really love Jean
column6: but some clone or piece of her or whatever.  That's just dumb.  This all leads up to the Inferno storyline that was dismal.  A very weak conclusion to Mr. Sinister/Jean Grey/Madelyne Pryor storyline.  It was a poor poor poor (have i mentioned poor?) decision to raise Jean from the dead.  We had all moved on and had our memories of her and the glory days of the X-Men title.  The decline of the X-Men as a title is a whole other story.  The book stayed good for a few more years after (prob up to the early #200s)
column7: and had splashes of brillance here and there (Jim Lee art)
column8: but after Claremont and Byrne parted ways there was definitely a decline in the title culminating in the horrible Inferno storyline and the eventual splitting into 2 teams (another bad idea). So are Captain America's original sidekick Bucky and Spidey's old flame Gwen Stacy coming back too? Jean Grey coming back to life was/is a BAD IDEA!! A bunch of baloney! I still call myself an X-Men fan
column9: but I am a fan of the large box full of back-issues I have.  All you younger fans out there (I'm 27) need to read up on the old school and see how great this series used to be

column1: Interesting experimental fiction.  In Big Trouble
column2: Barry employs the technique of shifting protagonists so well that in the end the reader isn't sure who the story is about.  Characters are abandoned with abandon and neglected through carelessness
column3: leaving a laser sharp focus on what the novel is really about--which is not the psychodelic frog.  It's something less original.  The genre is also well disguised.  Is it a comedy or a thriller?  If a novel is funny
column4: can we take the thriller part seriously enough?  In some cases
column5: yes.  When
column6: for example
column7: the comedy is built on clever dialogue by characters truly capable of mayhem.  In this case
column8: no.  It's a little jarring when a comic cop is traveling around
column9: chained to an entertainment center
column10: while a teenage girl is in the clutches of a sex-oriented crazy.  In all fairness
column11: the novel does feature a ticking clock
column12: which is handy to have in a thriller.  It's more effective if there is something believable about the story.  I expected a novel with an overdose of silliness
column13: but I was spared that
column14: which was a plus.  No characters with absurdly meaningful names.  The nuts and bolts aspect of writing was competently performed.  While there was little depth to any characters
column15: that's probably less of a requirement for characters  we want to laugh at.  The characters could have used some personality
column16: but that's a common flaw.  The novel should have been funny in places
column17: for a list of situations would show some potential.  But I had no difficulty keeping a straight face throughout.  Others would disagree.  The politically incorrect portrayal of Miami was entertaining
column18: if not actually funny.  The overall effect of reading Big Trouble is to bring about a yearning for the days when an editor would say
column19: "Sir
column20: I know your name is a household word
column21: and I know we could make money on whatever you write
column22: but I have to turn down too many good novels to give a green light to...to something like this."  If there ever were such days.

column1: Having heard so much about this revisionist school
column2: I was propelled to read this book.  Such unscientific biased absurdity certainly has some motive behind it. Interestingly enough
column3: many of the details within could be used as a treatise behind Herman Goering's testimony at Nuremburg that the extermination of Jews
column4: gypsies and countless others never happened. They merely died of starvation in war-like conditions.  This book ignores detailed existing records that document orders and transport of Zyklon B for the vast death camp complexes.   How can one even concoct theories like those within when there are still numerous witnesses alive who watched Jews enter the gas chambers and then retrieved the bodies? (Sonder Kommandoes). Perhaps the eyewitness accounts of Jews are not admissible evidence to these "scholars"?  With regard to the author being persecuted and driven from his  country
column5: I have no compassion since he and his family

column1: Schuller desires to take the reader down a feel-good road.  Unfortunately
column2: the path is littered with little more than cliches and pop-psychology.  The text is a series of sound-bytes which is easily equalled or surpassed in most any book of collected quotations
column3: or
column4: if one prefers
column5: a Google-search under choice key words.  The road signs of the book (i.e. the gist of the text) are 1) you feel unfulfilled; 2) don't worry
column6: be happy; 3) oh yes
column7: and God wants you to be happy.  All the road signs are supplemented with the above-mentioned sound-bytes and pop-psychology.  In keeping with the spirit of the book
column8: I took the path and stopped at Schuller's lemon tree.  Unfortunately the lemons were not good.  I then tried to make lemonade.  Unfortunately the lemons were so bad that no amount of sweetner could make them palatable.  In fact
column9: it became unhealthy.  I tried several other uses
column10: but all were equally unproductive and unhealthy.  I began to wonder why--then I realized that lemon trees
column11: in order to produce palatable fruit
column12: must be trimmed regularly.  The lemon tree at the side of this particular road is in need of serious trimming.  There is better and more nutricious fruit to be found elsewhere.  Even the old cliche "when life gives you lemons
column13: make lemonade" is of no use when the tree itself is no good.  It is this last part that Schuller fails to adequately address.  Too bad.  I strongly suggest you take a different and more scenic road that bears much better fruit

column1: Given the nature of things online and how easy it is to misrepresent something as being *THE GREATEST EVER*
column2: I am usually skeptical when any book has glowing reviews and it's only been out less than a month.  I hate to burst the shiny bubble that the other two reviewers have given but Christopher Hart's books are not worth the time or the money for the serious would-be comic book artist or established artist looking to improve.  Don't just take my word for it though go to your local library or bookstore and have a look at Hart's books yourself.  In all of his books on superhero drawing and manga style drawing
column3: you will find no more than 25 pages of artwork done by Hart.  This book I believe only has 16 - 18 pages of art attributed to him out of 144 pages.    So exactly who fills out the rest of Hart's books?  A number of other artists who draw considerably better superheroes and villains in American
column4: Manga and Fusion style than Hart can.  It's a shame those artists don't have their names listed on the book covers.  To even put Hart's name on the cover as though he'd done all the work (or even most of it) is very misleading.  Again
column5: don't just take my word for it
column6: visit your library or bookstore and look for the contributing artists listed in the first few pages of the book.  You will quickly find that Hart is good at drawing very basic and general characters but not the type of superheroes that populate comic books.    Now you might think well if the other artists are pretty good isn't the book still worth it?  No and the reason I say this is because I've seen them and most every one is light on technique and instruction. How light? Try a page or two at best on topics like facial expressions
column7: poses
column8: clothing etc.  There are better books out there which are more in depth and devoted to one or two topics rather than skimming over many as Hart's books do.  I can only guess that the popularity of comic books
column9: comic books turned movies and videogames based on comics has served to fuel the book buying of how-to drawing books that have made Hart a best-seller.  It's also served to prompt many others to toss crappy how-to draw books out there as well.  Sadly
column10: there's at least three worthless drawing books for every solid book on comic book/superhero drawing.  With the string of Hart books coming out seemingly one after another
column11: that ratio of bad over good will only continue to grow.    I just hope that more people discover the truth about books like this one and not buy them sight unseen based on the sales rank or number of glowing reviews. Hopefully the result will be fewer sales and ultimately fewer useless books clogging up the market.

column1: I am on my third off-camera cord (about one per year).  Two have broken.  As other reviewers noted
column2: the four screws under the metal retaining clip on the "female" end of the cord loosen and eventually fail.  I have found that a thin narrow knife can be used to remove the black "spring" cover over the screws on the shoe.  You can then tighten the screws with a screwdriver.  If you use Locktite on the screws then they will not loosen.  Canon should do this at the factory.  I use this cord with a Stroboframe "portrait/landscape" grip which raises the flash over the camera by six inches thus eliminating red eye and providing a much more pleasing light.  The stroboframe grip comes with the right size threaded screw for this cord.  When my cords failed I lost the extended-through the lens metering just like another reviewer noted.  I am not a professional photographer and only use the camera occasionally yet the cord still fails.  Canon should re-engineer this cord to make it more durable.    Unfortunately
column3: I do not believe that there are alternative cords. It looks like I will need to keep buying Canon cords

column1: The result of using Outlook the way this author recommends is that you'll essentially have two separate lists:  one list of all your projects and another list of all your "next actions".  Since you'll be able to sort your next-action list according to the context in which each action will be done
column2: this arrangement is better than nothing.  But the problem with this arrangement is that with it
column3: Outlook maintains neither project-to-next-actions connections nor next-actions-to-project connections.  The author would have you list "next actions" within each project's Notes field to link the project to its next actions
column4: and the author offers no link of each next action back to its project.    The author has missed a simple
column5: powerful solution to this problem.  When using Tasks in Outlook
column6: the Tasks folder offers a heirarchical directory structure in which it's very easy to add folders and subfolders
column7: just as one might do in Windows Explorer.  Each of these folders that you create can be named to represent a project
column8: and the next actions for each of these projects can be stored within the project's folder.  Then all you have to do to see a list of all your next actions (across all projects) is to run a quick "Advanced Find" on your Outlook Tasks folder.  Once you get the criteria of your search the way you want them
column9: your search criteria can easily be saved
column10: allowing you to recreate your "next actions" list with current data whenever you want it.  If you include the "In Folder" field to display in your search results
column11: then this field provides your next-action-to-project connection; and when you're reviewing your Outlook Tasks folder
column12: the directory list of folders is essentially your project list
column13: and within each project you see only the next actions associated with that project
column14: so it's easy to maintain a project focus when planning your projects.  Also
column15: when using Outlook this way
column16: many additional Outlook features can be used as well.  This book offers a few good ideas
column17: but by failing to describe a simple and powerful way to have Outlook itself maintain the association of each project to its next actions
column18: this book cannot be strongly recommended

column1: Dr Laura gives some good advice but it is mixed with absolutely stupid advice such as when she says that a person should stay in an unhappy marriage because of their commitment.  It is unfortunate that she chose to use this relationship book as her soapbox to promote her own religous beliefs. If you dont believe in God and as Dr Laura
column2: you can never be happy is the moral of her story. Laura makes a number of irresponsbile and misleading statements such as calling daycare
column3: modern child abandonment. She talks about chastity until marriage several times and about 'shacking up' to use her term but never once does she explain why monogomy is important in a healthy relationship and she absolutely never mentions that a relationship has a natural progression part of which is physical. She moves the step of marriage up to be much sooner than it should be in a relationship while at the same time saying people should wait 'through the 4 seasons' or a year before being married. Actually says 'it is dangerous to pursue a physical relationship without the promise of marriage'. Is she saying men should promise marriage before they are ready?  She would have produced a much better book if she had given more examples of callers to her radio show or letters and given less malformed advice. Her rants and raves are actually entertaining
column4: too bad that along with examples were cut short with her religious promotions and poorly thought advice snippets.  I listened to the whole thing(audio book cd) and I couldnt list the 10 stupid things implied in the title. I guess they are there and maybe under chapters 1-10 in the book. I could call out several stupid things but I didnt see 10 that stood out. Lots of it was common sense and phsychologically off callers made it obvious.  It is fun to listen to but make sure it is not the only book you use as a source. There are other better sources for relationship info.

The other annoying thing was his promotion of network marketing as a good business option. It was obviously done to help sweeten the deal he has with the network marketing association who recommend all his books to their members.   I could seriously go on and on about why you shouldn't waste your money on this book but I won't.  I have NEVER written a book review on amazon before as I have never felt so strongly about a book. I generally feel if I get even just 1 thing out of reading a book then it was well worth it. In this case I didn't get anything out of it and felt really used and taken advantage of which is why I decided to post this review.   I hope it saves someone else from wasting their money. Buying this book WILL NOT HELP YOU RETIRE YOUNG OR RETIRE RICH
