column1: Because of its popularity and its subject matter
column2: I was very excited to read Chalmers' The Conscious Mind. I was horribly disappointed.  First
column3: Chalmers' discussion of supervenience and intension in chapter two is horribly convoluted. Of course
column4: Chalmers asterisked some of the more technical parts of this chapter so that the lay reader could skip them
column5: but here's the problem: if you skip these sections
column6: you are no longer able to critique the most crucial parts of Chalmers's argument!   Second
column7: Chalmers engages in bizarre and fallacious reasoning. One of his central arguments runs like this: It is possible to imagine a zombie---that is
column8: a being who is molecule-by-molecule identical to me
column9: but who lacks phenomenal conscious experiences (i.e.
column10: qualia). Since imagining this involves no obvious logical contradiction
column11: zombies must be logically possible. Since zombies are logically possible
column12: qualia must not supervene on physical facts--that is
column13: qualia are not logically dependent upon the physical. Since this is true
column14: there can be no possible reductive
column15: materialistic explanation of consciousness.  This argument is preposterous on its face
column16: as many reviewers have noted
column17: and it is only the hocus-pocus about supervenience and intension in chapter two which lends it even a little credibility. For example
column18: let's assume that reductive explanation X can fully explain consciousness in terms of brain functioning. Even if this is true
column19: it is STILL possible for us to imagine zombies right NOW---purely because of our ignorance of X. Since the zombie argument is a central pillar of Chalmers's text
column20: its failure is a failure of the book as a whole.  Third
column21: Chalmers has not done his homework when it comes to the arguments of other philosophers. For example (leaving aside the technical details)
column22: I would suggest reading Quine's essay "Two Dogmas of Empiricism" in From a Logical Point of View. Then
column23: read Chalmer's discussion of Quine's arguments in chapter two of this book. Then reread Quine's essay (it's a tough essay). Chalmers utterly fails to refute Quine's arguments
column24: and these arguments are absolutely fatal to Chalmers's entire enterprise--especially his ridiculous zombie argument.  Finally
column25: Chalmers does not address previous attempts to explain qualia (phenomenal conscious experiences) reductively. Daniel Dennett
column26: for example
column27: spends an entire chapter of Consciousness Explained trying to provide just such a reductive explanation. Since Chalmers's whole point is to argue that the existence of qualia specifically makes reductive explanations of consciousness impossible
column28: his failure to spend even two pages on Dennett's explanation is ridiculous. (Briefly
column29: Dennett argues that qualia just are the sum total of all a person's visceral
column30: cognitive
column31: emotional
column32: etc. repsonses to a particular object of perception.)  In its foundations
column33: its approach
column34: and its failure to address important arguments by Quine
column35: Dennnett
column36: and others
column37: this book is an abject failure. Instead
column38: I would strongly suggest purchasing the wonderful and varied essay collection Explaining Consciousness: The Hard Problem.

column1: This book
column2: like the Atkins approach in general
column3: has part of the picture
column4: but is certainly incomplete.  Moderation
column5: not virtual elimination
column6: of carbohydrates
column7: when paired with lean protein
column8: plenty of omega 3 (fish and flax oils)
column9: and monounsaturated oils (like olive oil)
column10: has been shown to be the healthiest diet (a Mediterranian type diet). The Atkins approach does not advocate moderation
column11: instead prefering to vilify an entire necessary macronutrient - carbohydrates!  Certainly the old fashioned 1980's style high carb low fat diets were a disaster
column12: and brought out diabetes in susceptible people - but the answer is balance - good quality
column13: naturally high fiber carbs
column14: paired with protein and healthy fat - not virtual elimination of carbs.  Inadequate carbohydrate intake can lead to fatigue and reluctance to exercise.  Dr. Vernon herself continues to struggle with her weight
column15: despite following the Atkins approach. Most Americans will initially lose weight when starting on Atkins because most eat FAR too many carbs.  But they also eat too much saturated fat (animal and dairy fat
column16: for the most part)
column17: which has been show to worsen insulin problems and diabetes
column18: and aggravate cholesterol and artery inflammation
column19: worsening risk of heart disease and stroke.  Atkins addresses one of the these culprits (excess sugar)
column20: but not the other (excess saturated fat).  Americans need to cut down on these
column21: and then add more good fats (fish
column22: nuts
column23: olive oil
column24: avacado)
column25: lean protein (to cut down on saturated fat)
column26: and not be afraid of healthy carbs in the form of whole fruits (not juice)
column27: vegetables
column28: and whole grains (not white bread or sugary low fiber cereal).  That
column29: plus watching the calories
column30: and daily exercise (at least 30 " of moderate cardio
column31: five days a week)
column32: and diabetes will DRAMATICALLY improve.  Try it and see! Health is not just about weight - its about healthy body fat and muscle ratios

column35: etc.  The studies all support healthy balance.

column5: if this memoirs is anything to go by.  The structure of the book is as self-consciously clever-clever as is the title. A grab bag of memories scattered like cushions over the overstuffed horsehair sofa of the ultimate prissy literary queen.

column1: "Battle" appears to be written as a direct challenge to Victor Davis Hanson and John Keegan
column2: two of the world's best known military and classical historians.  Dr. Lynn's book is well written and well organized
column3: and provides a fascinating overview of his thesis on how cultural discourse affects the waging of war by societies.  He aggressively asserts that there is no "Western" (or other non-Western) Way of War
column4: rather that each culture's interpritation of war and battle shapes its values and how it fights its wars.  His work deserves great consideration
column5: but I will not go so far to say that he necessarily "disproves" the analysis put forward by Hanson or Keegan.  Regrettably
column6: his book would receive more stars were it not for his Epilogue concerning the War on Terrorism.  The Epilogue reads more like a treatise from the editorial pages of the New York Times and less like a sober understanding of the challenges this unique War presents.  His choice of source material for the Epilogue includes Maureen Dowd
column7: Richard Clark and Gen. Anthony Zini.  Dowd cannot be taken seriously
column8: and Clark has been thoroughly discredited.  Zini is in the mold of Gen. Wesley Clark.  By stepping in to this highly politicized debate and adopting the positions of those so firmly on the Left
column9: it undercuts my opinion of his otherwise interesting and informative work.  However
column10: it deserves to be read by those who share Hanson's and Keegan's analysis
column11: as it is a worthy challenge

column1: My 3 and 4 year olds just were not really interested in this book.  Wish we'd just checked it out at the library instead
Firstly
column2: this is a really quick read. I read the entire book on my lunchbreak. IMHO anytime one can do that there wasn't lots of thought behind the writing and this book holds true to that rule.   I thought the book smacked of a huge ego with a touch of arrogance. Mr. Vincent mentions his most famous line "Go home and get your shinebox" from Goodfellas
column3: at least eight times over the course of a few hundred pages. Do we really need to hear it again and again? I think not.  He also talks down to his audience in such a way that if you are not spending $25 for your Double R Davidoff cigar or dropping $250 on flowers for your date then you are not a "man's man". Not all of us are working actors who earn six figure incomes and can afford such luxuries. Most of us are regular guys making $40-60K per year who are in need of a few tips hear and there.   I know it is a tongue in cheek kinda book but Mr Vincent should come back to reality when it comes to how much you need to spend in order to impress your date. If all it takes is money to impress then most of us are out of luck. And if all she is looking for anyway is a sugar daddy then who really wants to be with her in the first place?   Save your money and wait for the paperback or better yet
column4: get it from the library

column1: Naturally

column11: since my hair is already dry enough!). The movements were clumsy with this
column12: and I occasionally snagged my hair or burned myself due to the plates unexpectedly shifting toward me. It didn't break
column13: and it's still going just as strong as the day I first bought it.  This straightener had problems dealing with smaller amounts of hair
column14: or the fine "baby hairs" around my forehead. And sadly
column15: it couldn't keep my side bangs straight to save its life -- they were as wavy as ever two hours after I'd straightened it. This straightener does the most minimal job -- at least it straightens your hair somewhat -- but save your pennies for a straightener more worthwhile.

column1: Dow Jones is still going through its major corrections after the roaring 80s and then the 90s. We are experiencing the same cylical phase that happened in the 70s - when war
column2: energy crises
column3: international market expansions
column4: and demographic changes were gradually driving the economy to a malaise.  The main difference is that the country was in little debt 30 years ago. We are now owing other countries trillions of dollars
column5: and the trade deficit will continue to soar. The economy may sink as a result
column6: but it has nothing to do with bubble bursting. That was already done in the stock market years ago. Should the economy finally collapse
column7: it will have to do with our structural economic problems.   Most probably prefer a soft-landing rather than a hard collapse. It will take some sacrifice and some political leadership to achieve a peaceful and endurable transition. It will be about our committment to paying down the debt
column8: ending our oil dependence
column9: and educating the workforce to take on the jobs of the new century that are not to be "outsourced" to other places.   As this review is being written
column10: the alleged "greater bubble" has yet to be materialized. However
column11: stocks will NOT emerge into a greater bubble unless the American people can become optimistic about the economy again. Dent has been wrong in his past predictions
column12: so please do not take this book too seriously either

column24: brutish

column27: so he's still got some 20 years to not look like an utter nincompoop.  But I could tolerate the misguided ranting if the rest of the book were good.  It is not.  The biggest problem is the oppressive dreariness of it.  This stems largely from the fact that Lawrence only ever seems interested in writing about emotionally crippled people (so much so that I strongly suspect  that he was emotionally crippled himself).  Every character is decidely neurotic
column28: each in their own special flavor.  The closest thing we have to a representative of mental health would be Mrs. Bolton.  The central character Connie does eventually get her head screwed on straight by the end of the book

column1: I find it hard to believe that the author has even visited Cuba
column2: let alone lived there. Not being an American
column3: I have legally spent quite a bit of time in Havana myself - and not as a tourist
column4: either - and there are so many glaring inconsistencies between this book and the realities it describes
column5: I would have sworn it was written by someone who was only going on third-party descriptions and their own wild imagination.  Jineterismo is indeed a gaping wound in Cuban society
column6: but it certainly doesn't work the way this book describes it - quite far from it. There is a lot of uncommon ground between Cuban-style jineterismo and generic western-type prostitution
column7: and this author's take is remarkably closer to the second one. To give an example: no Cuban jinetera would be "sitting by herself" anywhere
column8: let alone at a "cafe near the Habana Libre Hotel
column9: and with a stack of papers" in front of her no less. That picture is straight out of the US
column10: and anyone doing said things in Cuba would never
column11: ever be mistaken for anything other than a foreigner
column12: not even by the naivest American tourist. More importantly
column13: the jineteras sell romance more than they sell sex
column14: which is amongst the most alluring things about them. One may pay them
column15: but one is always left with the impression that they're being generous and "helping out" someone with whom they had a good time
column16: not contemptuously paying a professional for services rendered as described in the book.  The book may be enjoyable as a read - I don't know
column17: as personally I was unable to finish it for being so annoyed with the false picture it paints. My own impression is that it is naive and rather sophomoric. If you do choose to read it
column18: please keep in mind it is pure fiction. If a literary glimpse into modern-day Cuba (shocking underworld included) is what you're after
column19: there are far better books out there by Cuban authors
column20: and even an excellent relevant collection of short stories and book excerpts

column1: Hardly being a serious look into the (supposed) simulated world
column2: Simulacra and Simulation unnecessarily confuses
column3: compounds
column4: and over-estimates the reality of simulation
column5: and implies simulation in virtually everything while failing to give any real evidence or examples for this phenomenon. Through and through
column6: Baudrillard fails to adequately define his terms
column7: concerns
column8: and sources for his critiques. While never settling on one particular point
column9: his arbitrary method of critiquing never moves beyond the realm of opinion. Critical analysis of the subject matter (whatever that is) is never applied
column10: instead being sacrificed for ever more obscured superficial observations. Baudrillard gives us no example as to the cause of his concerns (whatever those may be) let alone giving us any real solutions as to how we may pierce through our alleged self created illusions. Nor does he give us any real insight as to how these critiques can be applied in any useful way to our education or our daily life. If this is what is passing for philosophy today
column11: I can only imagine how useless the field will become in fifty years if we continue to look to Baudrillard as the top of his field. Superfluous and meaningless double-talk is all you will get out of this useless excuse for a book. For anyone interested in reading "Simulacra and Simulation"
column12: I would sooner recommend Dr. Seuss "Green Eggs and Ham." You will have more fun reading it
column13: and you will probably learn more as well

column1: There is one aspect of this book about which I DO have firsthand knowledge - and that concerns my first cousin  Jim Channon
column2: about whom Mr. Ronson writes at great length.  I know Jim Channon to be a highly imaginative and creative visionary artist who sincerely seeks to influence the human populations of this planet to cooperate rather than annihilate one another in acts of senseless warfare.  I know from firsthand discussions with my cousin Jim that his First Earth Battalion concept is an attempt to unify the military establishments of this world in an altruistic common cause - to substitute worldwide cooperation in preserving this planet in place of the centuries of bloody conflict which has historically been centered around violently competing religious ideologies.    An earlier complimentary book reviewer of "...Goats" - Constance E. Cumbey - has penned her own scathingly biased hit piece (Hidden Dangers of the Rainbow) which decries the "New Age" movement and claims that its proponents' desire for worldwide cooperation rather than religiously motivated warfare would somehow lead to "barbarism".  (What???)  I suppose she believes that the centuries of bloody warfare which HAVE been fomented by the differing beliefs of the three worldwide religions (Judaism
column3: Christianity
column4: and Islam)
column5: - each of which claim to be the ONLY correct way of following the dictates of their version of the "God" of Abraham
column6: - would be preferable to worldwide cooperation?!  No surprise there.  All religious fundamentalists apparently believe that ANYONE who disagrees with their chosen form of worship is going to "hell"
column7: anyhow... so why not just kill them all and send them there posthaste
column8: right???  Heaven forbid that modern secular idealists would rather seek a means of worldwide understanding and mutual cooperation instead of conventional military industrial warfare! My god!  Haliburton would go bankrupt!!! 8-P  Mr. Ronson mischaracterizes my cousin Jim Channon as an incredibly wealthy and seemingly insane man who owns a mountaintop in Hawaii and behaves like a warlord in his neighborhood. Rubbish!  This is not only ridiculous - it is libelous.  Jim owns three acres at the top of the hill in a rural Hawaiian community
column9: on which he has constructed a beautiful outdoor garden amphitheater (where his daughter was married)
column10: a guest house
column11: a yurt
column12: and an open-air and open-beam rustic residence in which he runs no air conditioning and communes with nature to the extent that he kills no creature that chooses to inhabit it with him.  There are geckos clinging to the walls.  There are occasional spiders in the corners.  There is a kitty cat.  When his sister
column13: my cousin Elizabeth Channon Jones
column14: asked him why he didn't even choose to kill the spiders
column15: Jim replied
column16: "They're creatures too!". Does THIS sound like a man who would recommend or condone the practice of attempting to kill animals or human beings with mental or psychic energy?  A 'flowerchild'
column17: perhaps... a true 'nature boy'
column18: perhaps... but a nutcase who thinks he's a warlord? NO. I'm afraid that with this "Staring at Goats" book Mr. Ronson qualifies as a Spin-Meister and practitioner of hyperbole for purposes of profit.    Jim Channon trusted this man
column19: opened his home
column20: and shared some of his most personal and heartrending experiences in Vietnam.  In return for his trust he was smeared in this sensationalistic little exercise in spin.  The First Earth Battalion is Jim Channon's imaginative
column21: futuristic
column22: and creative concept for a worldwide cooperative military force whose mission would be to preserve this planet for posterity and to replace conventional warfare with visionary tactics of mind-expansion and compassion.  The non-lethal tactics he proposed
column23: based upon new age psychic research and experimentation prevalent in the 1970's - `80's
column24: was never intended to be utilized for purposes of torture.  It was intended to be mind-altering and mood-altering in the hope of dissuading prospective combatants from killing one another.  Idealistic?  Certainly.  But this man (who won't even kill a spider in his own home) never EVER intended his suggestions to be used for purposes of killing innocent animals... or for torturing prisoners.    Subliminal suggestions have been proven to be successful.  Sound does affect one's equilibrium and state of well being. But ask Senator John McCain if he believes that being forced to listen to the "Barney the Dinosaur" song: "I love you
column25: you love me
column26: we're a happy family..." constitutes anything remotely approaching "torture".  Give me a break!!!  This does a gross injustice to the likes of Senator John McCain and anyone else who has genuinely experienced TORTURE.  McCain's bones were broken... his joints were dislocated... his face shows the scars.  If listening to "Barney The Dinosaur" singing for several days in a row induces some potentially suicidal/homicidal religious zealot to spill the beans
column27: I'm GLAD.    So based upon my personal knowledge concerning Lieutenant Colonel (ret) Jim Channon and his imaginative First Earth Battalion THINK PEACE (pun intended)
column28: I take this entire "Staring at Goats" book with a large lump of rock salt.  I sincerely hope that we DO see the day when my cousin's visionary concept of dedicating the world's manpower to preserving this Earth (instead of wiping each other off the face of it) comes to fruition.

column1: George Page is a journalist
column2: not a researcher. Unfortunately
column3: that does not save him from taking the posture of one who knows better. He dismisses whole fields of discourse with offhand remarks
column4: for example: "Eventually behaviorism melded with the equally notorious sociobiology as formulated by E. O. Wilson." (p. 29) For an accessible yet scholarly exploration of animal cognition
column5: I recommend Marc Hauser's "Wild Minds." Hauser is a scientist
column6: who specializes in primate cognition. His writing is more lucid
column7: and less affected. He addresses the same questions as Page
column8: with an appreciation for subtle variaritions in the possible interpretations of evidence
column9: which is lacking in Page's presentation. One comparison between the books: Page's bibliography is 3 pages long; Hauser's spans 30

column1: The Moviegoer is a book about a 30 year
column2: disaffected businessman.  He's successful and liked
column3: from a rich New Orleans family
column4: but bored with life. He doesn't know what he wants
column5: and doesn't know what to do about it.  This description
column6: however
column7: sounds like Binx Bolling
column8: the main character
column9: is actually doing something to figure out what's wrong.  Unfortunately
column10: the book just follows him around through his life over the course of a week and describes his boredom and dissatisfaction with the things around him.  While interesting from a theoretical
column11: philosophical
column12: existential point of view
column13: it makes for boring reading.  In addition
column14: the book
column15: released in 1960 feels badly dated
column16: about a time and place that no longer exists
column17: so while I have experienced my own bouts of existential angst
column18: Binx's problems are not mine and the book is not written in a way to help sympathize with his plight. This is in stark contrast to Kafka
column19: for example
column20: whose stories of frustration and nothingness from 19th century Prague can bring me to tears.    While the novel is set in New Orleans
column21: there is little description to make the unique setting visible other than the names of a few streets. Similarly
column22: Binx remains a faceless everyman
column23: and the women he dates so interchangeable that Binx himself can barely keep them distinct.  The title
column24: too
column25: is misleading.  "The Moviegoer" made me expect a story about a person who lived his life through characters in the movies.  While Binx does attend movies regularly and describes people in terms of long forgotten actors
column26: I have to assume the title refers to Binx's problem of watching life around him without participating the same way as we watch a movie.    Like the existential play "Waiting for Godot" this story is mostly about the lack of a story
column27: and though things happen
column28: there is little sense of suspense or caring to carry the narrative forward.   If you're looking for an existential novel
column29: I'd strongly recommend Kafka's The Castle or The Trial instead.  And if you're looking for an enjoyable novel that truly distills the distinctiveness of New Orleans with a truly memorable set of characters
column30: A Confederacy of Dunces (John Kennedy Toole) (which Walker Percy was instrumental in having published after the suicide of the author) is among the best novels of our times.  But The Moviegoer is a hard slog for little payoff.

column1: (Written for Worm's Sci Fi Haven by countezero
column2: more of his reviews can be read here: www.wormsscifi.com/haven)   To readers of a particular mindset
column3: specifically those who are outwardly contemptuous of authorities like government and law enforcement
column4: Philip K. Dick's Flow My Tears
column5: the Policeman Said (1974)
column6: will probably go down the gullet like manna. For readers less inclined to view their political and personal freedom as conditions that hinge on the whims of small-minded men in high castles
column7: the novel may not be so sweet.   Dick
column8: for those who are unfamiliar with him
column9: wrote 36 novels and five short story collections-one of which
column10: The Man in the High Castle
column11: won the Hugo award in 1962. He died in 1982 of heart failure just months before the release of Ridley Scott's Bladerunner
column12: which is based on the novel Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?. Thanks to his timely death-and Scott's bold theatrical vision of his work-Dick suddenly became a "poor man's Pynchon
column13: who, may be recognized as the greatest American novelist of the second half of the 20th century." Not bad praise for an author whose novels never made him much money and were mostly out-of-print until Harrison Ford doggedly pursued an outlawed band of replicants through rain-soaked Los Angeles streets on the silver screen.   What I've written above is the accepted biography
column14: the one published on the cover of his novels. It is factual
column15: but it is also too polite. The whole truth and nothing but the truth
column16: something which Dick professed simultaneously to worship
column17: wonder and write about
column18: is slightly stranger.   Would it surprise the readers of this review to learn Dick believed he had been contacted by pink laser beams from something called VALIS
column19: or the Vast Active Living Intelligence System
column20: which he described as one node of an alien artificial satellite network originating from the star Fomalhaut in the Pisces constellation? Further digging reveals:   "Dick claimed that he began to live a double life
column21: one as himself and one as Thomas
column22: a Christian persecuted by Romans in the 1st century C.E. Despite his current and past drug use
column23: Dick accepted these visions as reality
column24: believing that he had been contacted by a god-entity of some kind
column25: which he referred to as Zebra
column26: God
column27: and most often VALIS. He saw Rome as the pinnacle of materialism
column28: which
column29: after forcing the Gnostics underground 1900 years earlier
column30: had kept the population of the Earth as slaves to worldly possessions. Dick believed that VALIS had contacted him and unnamed others to induce the "impeachment" of Richard M. Nixon
column31: whom Dick believed to be the current Emperor incarnate."   Biography can either add illumination to a reader's comprehension of an author's works
column32: or it can muddle it. I've chosen to mention some of Dick's lesser known eccentricities because I believe it is almost impossible to understand Flow My Tears
column33: the Policeman Said without knowing something about the questionable beliefs and obvious passions that drove the man behind the rhetorical curtain to pull the particular plot levers he did.   Beyond the paranoid details Dick sprinkles throughout the opening pages of the novel-America is a police state in which everyone must carry I.D. cards
column34: college campuses have been closed off by the military and blacks have been sterilized to cut down on the crime rate-there isn't too much to gawk and gape at for the reader. A television celebrity named Jason Taverner
column35: who is the idol at the center of "the big worshipping world of viewers
column36: receives an interesting comeuppance from one of the attractive celebrity wannabes he's been spending some nocturnal hours with. Because Taverner has failed to land said Lady a record contract, as he promised, she shoots him in the chest with a Callisto cuddle sponge, some sort of life form which apparently has 50 feeding tubes that like to burrow into a person's chest. When he wakes up, alone in a dilapidated room, he discovers no one has the foggiest idea who he is. Even, his fellow celebrity lover, though Taverner possesses her private phone number and can describe a number of intimate details about her. But what's worse, remember folks he's living in a police state, is that there is no official documentation to prove anyone named Jason Taverner ever existed.   No celebrity, no status, no identity. I don't exist
column37: Taverner mentally moans. Existence being one of Dick's favorite topics, it's hard to read this line and not smirk. Taverner does exist, of course. He thinks, therefore he is. What's bothering him, beyond playing cat-and-mouse with the police, who know all about the forged papers he is forced to acquire, is that nobody recognizes him as Jason Taverner, celebrity extraordinaire-at one point, Taverner even discovers a selection of his records, but when he plays them they are blank.   Had the novel stayed with the idea of identity it might have worked. After all, what is identity? Are we are all self-contained solipsists, whose identities are totally the result of our own internal thoughts? Or are we shaped by our deeds and what other people think of them? Is a celebrity a celebrity simply because of the attention given to them, or do they possess some unquantifiable glimmer of brilliance? Certainly the people Taverner meets in the novel keep noticing special things about his post-celebrity-self, despite the fact they've never laid eyes on him before. He shines, he sparkles, he's handsome and he has a way with words and carries himself in a manner that defies ordinariness, even though for all intents and purposes he is no different than them. He's special, without having earned such an adjective.   But unfortunately, Dick abandons this promising narrative in favor of another. Enter Police General Felix Buckman, one of the police state's higher-ups who has a drug-addled, insane sister who ends up being the critical cog in the entire ebb and flow of events. As it turns out, Alys has been experimenting with a substance called KR-3, which bends time and space temporarily to create an alternate reality interlaced or superimposed over the actual one.   Anyone affected by it is forced to perceive irreal universes
column38: whether they want to or not...Taverner (who was affected with the drug) passed over into a universe in which he didn't exist. And we (the people he came into contact with) passed over with him because we're objects of his perception
column39: Buckman's aides explain.   Perception? Now there's an interesting theme. Too bad Dick fumbles it when he is trying to wrap up his novel with the above explanation. And if those fine words don't quite wrap things up for you, it's probably because any reader who comes to the end of the novel needs to know something about the beliefs of Dick's which I mentioned earlier.   In an essay entitled How to Build a Universe that Doesn't Fall Apart Two Days Later"
column40: Dick writes
column41: "The two basic topics which fascinate me are `What is reality' and `What constitutes the authentic human being?'" To this
column42: add and consider the following three statements.   1. "If reality differs from person to person
column43: can we speak of reality singular
column44: or shouldn't we really be talking about plural realities?"   2. "Reality is that which
column45: when you stop believing in it
column46: doesn't go away."   3. "I like to build universes which do fall apart. I like to see them come unglued
column47: and I like to see how the characters in the novels cope with this problem."   Flow My Tears
column48: the Policeman Said presents a perfect synthesis of these statements. For Taverner and Buckman
column49: the universe as they know it is certainly unglued. There is no one single reality in the novel
column50: there are at least two. But both realities are "real" because both of them continue to exist when the characters who exist within them wish they would go away.   So what then are we to make of the ending
column51: when a singular reality is ultimately restored? I was certainly baffled by it
column52: until I read the essay I quoted from above and came across Dick's bizarre claim that the novel is inspired by the Book of Acts
column53: from the Bible:   "A careful study of (Flow My Tears
column54: the Policeman Said) shows that for reasons which I cannot even begin to explain I had managed to retell several of the basic incidents from a particular book of the Bible
column55: and even had the right names. . . My theory is this: In some important sense
column56: time is not real. Despite all the change we see
column57: a specific permanent landscape underlies the world of change: and that this invisible underlying landscape is that of the Bible; it
column58: specifically
column59: is the period immediately following the death and resurrection of Christ; it is
column60: in other words
column61: the time period of the Book of Acts."   We are all
column62: in other words
column63: "fake humans" living in "fake realities"-with
column64: presumably
column65: Richard Nixon at the helm. Occasionally
column66: we are given glimpses of the truth
column68: but most of our lives are spent dwelling inside a contemporary dream. Brush it aside as we will find Tiberius ruling over Rome
column69: the apostles spreading the word. Exactly who or what has thrown the proverbial wool over our collective eyes
column71: I have not been able to learn in my brief bit of research for this article. Perhaps Dick
column72: who seems better informed than any of us
column73: wasn't privy to that information himself.   What does all this say about the plot of the novel
column74: about Taverner's experience inside an alternate reality
column75: which ultimate wasn't actual reality but an imagined one? To be honest
column76: I'm not sure. The epiphany in the novel-and the scene from which the title is pulled
column78: not Taverner. Exactly what revelation the scene conveys
column79: beyond eliciting sympathy from the reader for a character who up until that point has been entirely despicable
column80: I don't know. Felix cries. His sister
column81: who he also happened to be carrying on an incestuous relationship
column84: but to what end? Looking back at the essay one last time
column85: I see Dick hints at what he wants his audience to understand
column86: but see if you can follow his logic:   "(Buckman) is Christ himself returned
column87: to pass judgment. And this is what he does in my novel: He passes judgment on the man sealed up in the darkness. (On whom? Taverner?) It was judged and condemned. Felix Buckman could weep at the sadness of it
column88: but he knew that the verdict could not be disputed. And so he rode on
column90: hearing only the shriek of fear and defeat: the cry of evil destroyed."   Only Taverner didn't kill Alys
column91: Taverner is not convicted of killing Alys-what's more he didn't even know her in the novel's actual reality. He only met her in the novel's other reality. Is Dick saying we're guilty for the crimes we commit in both the realities he believes in? Are we judged in one world for what we do in another? I live those questions for my readers to answer. What I will say is that Dick's method has ultimately failed to convince me. His metaphor is strained and does not work. He misses
column92: or very rarely chooses to focus on what is
column93: or what might have been the core of an excellent novel. Instead
column94: an ultimately empty "dream within a dream" scenario
column95: something the professors who taught me creative writing in college told me to avoid is explored. Never end a story with "...and then I woke up
column96:
or its equivalent I was told in a stern voice by several different PhD's. With Flow My Tears, the Policeman Said, Dick does just that-and it's his zealotry for and his personal beliefs about the faulty nature of reality that have led him to such a disaster of flawed intent.    Two out of fiv

As Walter Laqueur observed in The Atlantic in his March 2002 review of this Gilles Kepel book
column2: his " obituary of Islamism was written before September 11."   What seemed truly astounding when I read this book four years ago was the extent of Kepel's knowledge--and his fundamental ignorance. I hadn't realized
column3: as I read
column4: that the original French edition of this book came out in 2000. Still
column5: it is extraordinary to think a scholar as widely read as Kepel could be so wrong
column6: as he is here
column7: as to pronounce radical Islam and jihad on the wane.   As the intervening years have proved
column8: nothing could have been further from the truth
column9: and of all people
column10: Kepel should have known it. But it was not Kepel's lack of knowledge concerning the origins of the Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt of the 1920s
column11: or the writings of Hassan al-Banna and his heir
column12: Sayyed Qutb (whom Nasser hanged in 1966) that lead to the author's blindness.   It was most likely Kepel's lack of understanding of the fundamentals of Islam itself. Like so many writers before and after
column13: Kepel blamed the rise of radical Islam on the backwardness of Middle Eastern society
column14: and the lack of political power of the rising middle class.   As Laqueur noted in The Atlantic
column15: Kepel laid the attractiveness of Qutb's radical "message and in particular his appeal to violence" to broad swaths of Egyptian society to several mostly economic and intellectual factors. Qutb resonated for "students who could not find jobs; the religiously observant lower middle class
column16: distrustful of modernity; and
column17: generally speaking
column18: all those disaffected by the state of affairs in the Muslim world who had become intellectually homeless after the failure of Arab nationalist ideology and of Marxism."  Actually
column19: however
column20: both Qutb's philosophy and its attractiveness to Egyptians and other middle eastern Muslims were powered by the same force--the fact that Qutb based his thinking and writings on the classical jurisprudence of Islamic scholars across the centuries. And in this respect
column21: Qutb was no different than many of the other radicals that Kepel covers
column22: including the violent Iranian religious revolutionary
column23: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini
column24: and Pakistan's Mawlana Mawdudi
column25: among others.   To understand the rootedness of these "radicals" in Islamic religious precepts and Islamic history
column26: Kepel ought to read Dr. Andrew Bostom's Legacy of Jihad.  Certainly
column27: Kepel is right about some factors that encouraged Islamic radicals to pursue their goals at the specific times that they did: In the 1980s and early 1990s
column28: Khomeinist fanatics terrorized Iran unchallenged
column29: Islamists seized power in Sudan and their cohorts had attempted coups in Algeria and Egypt as well. But more importantly
column30: ragtag Afghan Islamist armies eventually defeated the Soviet Union there
column31: and built a very successful propaganda campaign (though undoubtedly not entirely truthful) as a result.  But Kepel did not understand how Islamists saw their defeat and alienation from the Algerian majority
column32: Egypt's mass arrests of terrorists or Sudan's surrender of Carlos the Jackal to the French
column33: for criminal trial. To radicals
column34: these were merely temporary setbacks
column35: not the heralds of permanent defeat. Nor were the radicals at all discouraged by the rise of Iran's so-called moderate
column36: Mohammad Khatami (who was never really moderate) or the protests of Saudi women for the right to drive cars independently.   Worse
column37: Kepel did not understand that many Islamic scholars--whom he and many foolhardy others  presume to be "reformist" thinkers--are themselves reputedly central figures in the Muslim Brotherhood
column38: and in any case
column39: fundamentalists in their own right.   Take Tariq Ramadan
column40: the grandson of MB founder Hassan al-Banna
column41: whose visa application the U.S. State Department has twice
column42: rightfully

column44: ample evidence suggests Ramadan has links to terror. A 1999 Spanish police General Directorate memo

 The Sennheiser PMX70 had excellent sound quality and volume compared with others I'd used recently. I had high hopes on first listen. However, these semi-in ear headphones were moderately uncomfortable after only about 20 minutes. I later took them on a 40 minute run. The design is such that in any position I adjusted them, the speakers tilted slightly upward in my ear. Once I started perspiring, my sweat poured right into the little speakers. I had to stop every few minutes to shake the collected sweat out of the earpieces. The right speaker was filled with sweat and non-functional pretty much the entire run. Who designed these? Consider these headphones only if you 1) never plan to exercise while using them and 2) will be keeping them on for 20 minutes or less

column1: This book is inexplicably influential
column2: probably due to its catchy but ultimately meaningless title. Barber fails to convincingly analyze an interesting thesis
column3: instead delivering an exasperating 300 page-long list of every single thing on Earth that he disagrees with. Barber contends that natural human political behavior results in smaller and smaller ethnic enclaves trying to separate themselves from the larger world
column4: while unchecked global capitalism is erasing ethnic flavor with bowdlerized mass-culture sameness. Interestingly
column5: Barber contends that these two contrary movements are actually in an unholy alliance
column6: using each other's excesses as excuses for their anti-democratic behavior. That is a fascinating thesis
column7: which makes the weaknesses of this book all the more infuriating.   The first part of the book is an interminable tirade of lists within lists
column8: of cultural trends that Barber disdains
column9: in an avalanche of complaints that is not analytical but merely selective and arbitrary. It's all tied together with attempts at "edgy" pop culture references
column10: made-up terminology (like the annoying "infotainment telesector")
column11: and pseudo-intellectual quotations and namedropping. All is lumped together unconvincingly under the anemic term "McWorld
column12: which is so vague and all-inclusive as to become meaningless. In his never-ending examples of how recent cultural trends are damaging the freedom and intelligence of the masses, Barber merely comes across as a condescending snob who thinks his own interests are superior, or a curmudgeon who thinks everything was better back in the good old days, or both. In the second part of the book, Barber proceeds to throw obtuse political science theories at various world hotspots, in which tribalism and separatism are damaging the integrity of nation-states. His umbrella term for this phenomenon is the dangerously loaded term Jihad." Note that this book was published back in 1995
column13: so that word was not as prevalent in Western discourse as it is now
column14: but Barber still uses the term as a loose descriptor which is likely to offend both devout Muslims and ardent anti-Islamists.  When it comes to the specifics
column15: many reviews here and elsewhere list out the numerous flaws in Barber's arguments
column16: and there are so many of them that a lot of reviews are necessary for the task. You can agree or disagree with various critiques of Barber's contentions based on your own personal politics. But everyone will probably conclude that in this book's final section he does not deliver on the ironic implications of his initially intriguing thesis (embodied in the book's title)
column17: and simply forwards borrowed theories on civil society and the public sector. Overall
column18: this book is mostly the longwinded grumblings of a nostalgic know-it-all who portentously predicts doom for every single cultural and political reality of the modern world. [~doomsdayer520~

column1: First of all
column2: consider the question that Lewis is trying to ask. What went wrong with the 'Middle East' and their 'failure' to modernize? And now think about how big this book is
column3: about 150 pages. The 'Middle East' is a huge area extending from Morocco to Iran and he attempts to explain their 'failure' to modernize by reviewing the last years of the Ottoman Empire. That is just plain lazy work on the part of a historian who is supposed to be revered in his field.   Another issue is that he constantly refers to the 'Middle East' as 'Islam' as though Islam is homogenous or even centered in the Ottoman Empire. Granted the Sultan of the Ottoman Empire was also the Caliph but the Twelver Shi'is don't consider him to be legitimate anyway. To consider Islam to have some kind of collective thought process when encountering the 'West' is reprehensible. Consider now the fact that the majority of Muslims don't even live in the Middle East or the Ottoman Empire. How can Lewis truthfully use the term 'Islam' in his book to refer to the entity that 'went wrong' when the area he's speaking about doesn't even constitute the majority of Muslims in the world!?   This book is a quick read for people who aren't in the field to think that they're informed about what is going on in the scary area known as the 'Middle East'. The worst part is that the only people who would know that this is full of holes and lacking greatly in background and professionalism are the people who wouldn't normally read it anyway. This is a dangerous book because the name Bernard Lewis is synonymous with Expert in Middle East affairs. This was a lazy
column4: half hearted attempt to cash in on people's ignorance and only perpetuates the wrong ideas in people's minds. Bad Lewis
column5: very very bad. Any 'liberal historian' who suggests this book should be beaten with this book
column6: unfortunately for us the book is very thin so it will take a while to bring him down with it.  If you want better sources
column7: look to John Esposito
column8: Albert Hourani and Nikki Keddie. All of them have published widely and lack the obvious political biases of Bernard Lewis. Check them out.

column1: I will not lash out against anyone

column3: ostentatious egotism. That said
column4: let me merely point out that the absence of necessary historiographical context makes Jesus of Nathareth's solutions extremely difficult to accept. First off
column5: it doesn't do us much good to become angry and wave our arms and shout about the evils of Jesus's morals in general terms. If we want other people to agree with us and join forces with us

column7: circumvent any further litigation
column8: and violate his pledge not to condemn innocent people to death -- all by trumping up a phony emergency. His desire to control your bank account
column9: your employment

column11: and your mind is the chief sign that he's a slaphappy caitiff. (The second sign is that Jesus feels obliged to force me to undergo "treatment" to cure my "problem".)   Perhaps I'm reading too much into Jesus's ravings
column12: but they don't seem to serve any purpose other than to destroy the natural beauty of our parks and forests. Jesus's prcis are Pyrrhonism cloaked in the rhetoric of truculent
column13: noxious feudalism. That's pretty transparent. What's not so transparent is the answer to the following question: Does Jesus's oversized ego demand that he condone illegal activities? A clue might be that every time he tries
column14: Jesus gets increasingly successful in his attempts to have a serious destabilizing effect on our institutions. This dangerous trend means not only death for free thought
column15: but for imagination as well.   Jesus's eccentricity is surpassed only by his vanity. And his vanity is surpassed only by his empty theorizing. (Remember his theory that the cure for evil is more evil?) Jesus of Nathareth has an agenda -- a political
column16: social
column17: and cultural agenda. And that's all I have to say.

I wanted to like BROTHERHOOD
column2: for the simple reason that nearly every New Order fan this side of the galaxy has dismissed it
column3: usually with a faint whiff of snobbery (or at least apathy). Turns out they were right: BROTHERHOOD is half an album. Most of its nine songs feel unfinished
column4: as if the band wanted to cash in on the success of their 1985 smash LOW-LIFE and didn't care about the end result. BROTHERHOOD is a rush job
column5: plain and simple
column6: but there are still glimmers of hope within this bare-bones effort.   "As It Is When It Was" overcomes the album's overall muddy production by dint of being mostly acoustic
column7: and the melody is quite lovely. "All Day Long"
column8: the emotional centerpiece of the album by default
column9: is an intelligent (if half-hearted) protest against child abuse. While "Angel Dust" lacks a decent hook
column10: its subtly danceable beat and effective synth noodlings will at least briefly hold your interest. And the toss-off "Every Little Counts" has a charming sense of humor that is too often lacking in New Order's work.  The most popular song on BROTHERHOOD is
column11: of course
column12: "Bizarre Love Triangle". So good it seems to belong to a different album entirely
column13: "Bizarre Love Triangle" is truly New Order's masterpiece. The solid beat
column14: slick sequencer work
column15: and gorgeous melody showcase the band at their best: catchy
column16: danceable
column17: and downright euphoric. (Imagine how well it would have fit on LOW-LIFE.)  Sadly
column18: the rest of BROTHERHOOD is unremarkable. The album's production neatly mixes rock with electronic flourishes
column19: which has become New Order's signature sound
column20: but the songwriting doesn't measure up. Buy the album if you're a trainspotter
column21: but casual New Order fans would be better off picking up LOW-LIFE or 1983's POWER
column22: CORRUPTION AND LIES. This one is just a footnote.

column1: "You get what you pay for"  Most of the time that cliche is true

column6: you have to ask yourself
column7: why do you need a monopod over a tripod?  For myself and most
column8: it's because we need some stability and portability for our telephoto zoom lenses.    However
column9: telephoto zooms are long and heavy so the monopod should be designed strong and solid to live up to the task.  This monopod doesn't even come close.  Here are it's bad points:  -The aluminum construction is very cheap quality.  The leg segments wobble laterally when you extend and close them.  It feels like thin
column10: cheap aluminum and the monopod feels it could break in half like a toothpick at any time.  -The head is very cheap and not solid.  No matter how tight I tightened the head
column11: my camera would slope down.  The workmanship of the head is so cheap that at any point
column12: you think that you're going to break the PLASTIC tightening screw if you tighten it too much.  I think we've all experienced that in the past.  -The leg locks are not tight.  When you push down on the monopod
column13: the leg segments slide back into themselves.  In the end
column14: it was a risk I took hoping that I could get a high-quality product for a cheap price.  Sometimes
column15: you can get away with that.  Walmart sells a very decent functioning tripod for only $30.  In this case
column16: I should've bought a REAL monopod.  Oh well
column17: I wasted $16 that I could've used to help pay for a higher quality monopod

column1: Calling Cards... Long gloves vs Afternoon Tea gloves... How to prepare a proper wives luncheon complete with quiche???? WHO DOES THIS!!! As an Enlisted wife (And I find that most of the wives looking for help ARE Enlisted) you are going to wind up chucking this book right into the trash. The place on base that people keep mentioning as being useful is the Family Support Center. They have FREE reading material that is 400 times more useful than knowing what kind of gloves to wear to lunch. WHO WEARS GLOVES TO LUNCH?!! Half of the wives I know who "do lunch" end up showing up in jeans so where do the gloves come in??? I gave this to my best friend who is an Officers Wife

I didn't find this book revolutionary (which is how he seems to write it) or even particularly interesting. "Man's Search For Meaning" is a FAR more compelling leadership read...

column1: Think about Christianity.  About Catholicism

column4: at this point
column5: you will realize that there is absolutely no reason whatsoever to subscribe to it.  Christianity
column6: in its purest essence
column7: is submitting yourself to a mythical authority that you will never see
column8: hear
column9: touch
column10: or truly know.  It is the intellectual laziness of assigning all that you cannot explain about the world as the creation of an entirely unexplainable being - in other words
column11: refusing to admit the general ignorance of yourself and
column12: indeed
column13: the human race as a whole by claiming that the only reason you can't explain something is because it is inexplicable
column14: thus saving yourself the frightening strain of having to actually make an effort to think about anything.  And
column15: if God is indeed as arbitrary in his predestination as Luther and Calvin claimed
column16: why follow him?  (Claims about 'The Elect' are not an answer; in saying that God predestined only certain people to enter heaven
column17: but in acting morally you show yourself a likely member of that group
column18: Calvin merely gives the Catholic doctrine of "good works" a new name.)  As polemicized as the above may sound

column20: in trumpeting more ascetic
column21: predestination-oriented Christianity over the rich
column22: material hypocrisy of the established Catholic Church
column23: was merely  replacing a material
column24: class-based slavery with a moral slavery.  In claiming that Desiderus Erasmus' promotion of free will is merely an invitation to sin
column25: Luther shows his true colors.  He demonizes choice and diversion from "the true way" in order to convince others to follow him and add to his power.  Funny
column26: he wasn't quite so opposed to free will when he himself chose to defy the established Catholic order.  It is not wrong to enjoy alcohol
column27: sex
column28: or material possessions.  It is wrong to have these things while also preaching against them
column29: as the Catholics did
column30: but it is not wrong to enjoy the material pleasures of the world.  In Luther's steadfast opposition to other people enjoying themselves
column31: and advocacy of instead living your life according to a supposedly otherworldly moral authority which conveniently seems to have been revealed only to those who gain power
column32: we have merely the cynical and
column33: yes
column34: thoroughly materialistic manipulations of a man too bitter to acknowledge others any kind of pleasure
column35: independent thought
column36: or deviation from Luther's arbitrary set of standards.  The Catholics cynically exploited the masses by selling indulgences and fake relics through promises of a nonexistent paradise (see:  The Pardoner's Tale in Chaucer's Canterbury Tales).  The Protestants cynically exploited the masses by demonizing anything that might distract those masses' attention for one second from doing exactly what the Protestant leadership said (see: John Calvin's nightmarishly despotic Geneva).  Neither was any better than the other
column37: and both attempted to squash dissent mercilessly.  Luther's book is just another one of these attempts

column1: After years of hearing about what a seminal work this is
column2: I finally broke down and bought a (used) copy.  I expected something like the anti-Simon
column3: an exhaustive documentation of how we are inevitably headed toward doom and collapse unless the government steps in to intervene with specific recommendations.  I was extremely surprised to find that this book is nothing more than a long description of the authors' computer model!  Is that it?!  Apparently so.  The authors assembled a computer model of all human activity and natural science
column4: complete with feedback
column5: time delay
column6: and other parameters (yeah
column7: they really present it that way!).  Then they ran it through a computer and found what they expected - quite a surprise
column8: eh?  Then they tweak on the basic model and find that almost nothing leads to a rosy scenario.  Humanity is going to collapse by 2100
column9: and there is nothing we can do about it.  Well
column10: almost nothing.  Apparently
column11: if we stop procreating
column12: stop economic growth
column13: and spread the existing wealth evenly
column14: everything will be ... well
column15: it won't be great
column16: but it will be "okay"
column17: sorta like the warehousing activity that we call public "schooling".  I think there is a book that describes the resulting society
column18: ... I believe it was called _Anthem_.  I gave the book a couple of stars because of its canonical status
column19: but it certainly doesn't deserve the attention it has gotten.  A major flaw is that they don't describe the model they use in any significant detail to allow you to run the numbers yourself (they refer you to another article
column20: and you can find the original model on the internet if you're perseverent enough).  If someone is throwing this into your face as proof that we are headed to certain disaster
column21: fear not.  There simply isn't enough substance here
column22: some of the information and assumptions are dated
column23: and you can certainly point out a few holes in their model assumptions that tend to undo their long-term analysis.  If you are thinking about using this to support your world view
column24: please reconsider.  Try something a little more grounded in reality
column25: without the breathless hype
column26: like any environmental economics book by Tom Tietenberg

column1: I agree with Jodi (see her review further down) -- Teitelbaum is confused into thinking that the chronic fatigue he experienced as an overworked medical student is the same as Chronic Fatigue Syndrome.  True CFS (which involves neurologic
column2: endocrine
column3: cardiorespiratory and other abnormalities
column4: not merely extreme fatigue) has far more symptoms than just fatigue.  It's generally a result of a virus
column5: not "burn out".  For those who have real CFS
column6: some of the advice can be hazardous. Experts concur that exercise is detrimental
column7: especially to those in the advanced stages who have viral damage to their heart muscle ... I know several patients who've been rendered permanently bedridden after following misguided advice to exercise their way to health.  In fact
column8: reaction to exercise is one of the ways the experts differentiate between CFS and depression.  (see www.cfsfacts.org for details on this diagnostic shortcut)  I've tried Teitelbaum's Fatigued to Fantastic formula; even at maximum dosage
column9: it didn't put me to sleep.  It might help if you have chronic fatigue (the symptom) from insufficient sleep
column10: but Chronic Fatigue SYNDROME is not sleeping too little
column11: but not feeling refreshed when you wake up even if you've slept 20 hours.  See Jodi's list of good books about the Syndrome (not the symptom); I'd add David S. Bell's "Doctor's Guide to Chronic Fatigue Syndrome" as one of my top picks

Sad that someone can write as poorly as Patterson and sell oh so many books

column6: p.140).This fantastic science fiction forecast

column6: and Mac can't read the format of these drives).  Summation: I would not buy this again.  I am now looking at the Linksys product; it would require me to buy two HD enclosures

column1: Mere Christianity is a book often recommended to atheists by Christians and is touted as a rational
column2: logical case for the Christian religion. Unfortunately
column3: well-informed atheists will find that Lewis quickly uses a god of the gaps argument to explain his concept of Moral Law. Lewis's Moral Law argument will not fool anyone with a basic understanding of social evolution. All cultures have some prohibition against stealing and murder as well as some glorification of selflessness and compassion
column4: but this is due not to a Lawgiver but to social evolution. The reason we have these moral characteristics is because they helped us to survive. Any tribe of humans who permitted murder or glorified betrayal would fall apart and die out quickly.  A warning to all atheists who pick up this book: Don't bother reading past Book 1. The Moral Law is the keystone of Lewis's argument. Without it
column5: everything else he says is meaningless to atheists

column1: i have no idea how this movie managed to garner the reviews it has.  that this has been as heralded as it has shows a serious lack of respect for the genre.  this is a movie that has high aspirations
column2: but low standards
column3: disappointing both the cinema connoisseur AND action geek within me.  i respect what this movie was trying to do.  it wanted to be a crime thriller with a twist of hong kong action.  i've got no problem with that
column4: and in fact i've been waiting for a movie like that for years.  but the movie failed to execute this plan properly
column5: borrowing the wrong aspects from each of its derivative genres and turning it into the poster child of movies cited as reasons why action cinema deserves no legitimate consideration.  the basic premise was to make a crime drama
column6: but for the violent sequences to be choreographed into stylistic martial arts fighting.  the problem came when the filmmakers tried to mesh the two- they didn't know which elements to use from which genre.  the crime drama is filmed like an assembly-line fight movie
column7: with a confusing jumble of flashbacks ruining the pretty opening shot: pulse-light clips of a criminal being released from prison with 'hard' music behind it
column8: followed by a two-years-in-ten-seconds montage of a man adopting a little girl with 'drama' music behind it.  i was willing to forgive all this
column9: because the acting is actually very good here
column10: and i convinced myself that the explosion of violence i was anticipating would make everything worthwhile
column11: sort of 'equilibrium' style.  now

column13: his action is top-notch
column14: but what he tried to do here was ruined by the directing/editing.  firstly

column16: became a blur of hands
column17: then broke apart
column18: one of them maybe holding a bloody nose or something.  this is unneccesary.  katsu shintaro taught me that you don't need to speed film up for a man to be lightning-fast on camera.  'oldboy' taught me that you don't need to speed film up to have a totally captivating hand-to hand fight.  this movie couldn't wrap up the fight scenes fast enough.  second
column19: the fights broke into the ridiculous on occasion.  i don't like wires
column20: i don't like cg

column23: i wouldn't have had any problem with that.  but as mentioned
column24: this movie was also trying to be a legitimate crime drama
column25: so having skinny donnie yen THROW sammo hung over his head into a glass statue kind of tends to ruin any dramatic merit they may have earlier built up.  so
column26: since the brush of action had already corrupted the dramatic template
column27: i still would have forgiven the movie if the action had been good enough.  mind you
column28: i'm thrilled and content to have one single fight scene in a movie

column30: so i unconsciously came to expect there to be more action than i got.  the fights were few
column31: fairly compacted together
column32: and entirely too brief.  when they happened
column33: i had no idea what had just occurred
column34: only that two of the men who HAD been standing were now lying on the floor.  the ending was terrible

column1: A few years ago I spent nearly a year travelling around Australia
column2: and returned curious about some of the strange things I had seen there.  I  asked for this book for my birthday because of the good reviews it had  received on Amazon.com.  However
column3: when I finally got it none of my biggest  questions were addressed.  Previously
column4: most of my knowledge of these  subjects came from reading the little natural history bits in my Lonely  Planet Guide or by watching certain T.V. documentaries. I wanted a source  of information that went beyond these and revealed some of the underlying  explanations and science involved. I wanted to know the origins of some of  the famous landforms such as the Bungle Bungle or Ayer's Rock.  I'd also  wanted to know what shaped the dry interior.  I heard it was the bottom of  a sea at one time.  What the book does talk about in the geology section is  the split up of Gondwana in multi-paged depth
column5: and gives no more special  attention to Australia than other continents.  None of my questions were  addressed
column6: and the facts listed were not interesting to me.  In the section  on animals the author gave no real overview on their origins
column7: and just  listed a number of the most popular species and gave a little  characterization of each.  In many parts of the book I found that my  tourist's range of knowledge actually included some things the author  didn't mention
column8: such as how aboriginal burning shaped the ecology.   Also
column9: it often seemed that the author did not thoroughly know his subject matter
column10: but was just quoting from one of his sources. Eventually I began to loose  confidence that this book was written by an expert on the natural history  of Australia and more by a publication-hopeful writer (this is my opinion  based on his bio)who compiled an incomplete list of facts from numerous  sources
column11: some of which were pertinent
column12: others more randomly picked. The  book read like one giant research paper where the student sits down with a  stack of books on his subject and quotes pieces verbatim from all of them.   It also reads like an almanac.  That said
column13: this book does list a thousand  things previously unknown to me
column14: just not exactly the things I was after

column1: Midway is our Navy's greatest victory
column2: won against overwhelming odds and a battle-tested and hardened foe with superior aircraft. However Kernan considers our handling of the battle to be atrocious and holds many of the men who fought there and the Navy in disdain.  The press release states
column3: "Alvin Kernan
column4: who was present at the battle
column5: has written a troubling but persuasive analysis of...aspects of this great battle
column6: that it is a story of avoidable mistakes and flawed planning
column7: revealing enormous failures". From this one would presume we lost at Midway.  The promotional material offers up he was there and he was there - as an enlisted flight crewman.      The underlying theme of the book is incompetence and it is implied the navy was made up of drunkards
column8: buffoons or arrogant Academy types. Never mind that these same "buffoons" took on and defeated the greatest carrier force assembled in history and reversed the course of the war in the Pacific. Even worse is his carelessness with facts. The author states at Leyte Gulf the Japanese managed to get several escort carriers in their sights but were driven off.  This spurious treatment of facts ignores that TF Taffy 3 was comprised of 6 carriers
column9: where one escort carrier
column10: two destroyers and one destroyer escort were sunk in a desperate running gun battle. He states the Yamoto had 18 inch guns when they were 18.1" as well as getting the Yamoto's weight wrong by thousand of tons.  If you can't get the easy facts correct
column11: it casts doubts on your credibility.   It is too bad for there are some superior areas like his analysis of the flawed carriers constructed due to holding down costs with the Depression.  This same construction would prove to be a fatal flaw. His analysis of the flaws of the Mark 13 torpedo and torpedo doctrine are telling. He misses the point why the Navy did not do more practice with the torpedoes since budgets were so tight because of the Great Depression.   The American Navy knew after the Coral Sea that the TBD was outclassed by the Japanese Zero.  The author does not grasp that you often go to war with what you got - such as us having unarmored HMMWV's for Iraq. When he complains of our doctrine that led to the slaughter of the torpedo squadrons
column12: he implies Japanese tactics were better.  Kido Butai (their carrier strike force)  doctrine was launch a simultaneous strike from all carriers (mass) that was to arrive simultaneously.  Good in use of the principle of mass but inflexible and took longer to launch a strike - that led to their destruction at Midway. The friction of war caused our strike to go awry.    With an editor and a military historian to look at his writing and assertions with a critical eye
column13: this could have been a great addition.  As it is
column14: the book offers some interesting insights in training and the torpedo squadrons specifically but promises more than it delivers.

column1: I'm a pediatrician and have seen most of the physical and behavioral consequences of corporal punishment

column3: ever
column4: a need to strike an animal or a child.  Rather
column5: the approach called "Inductive Discipline" is far more effective.  Discipline is not synonymous with punishment
column6: and the approach takes note of the common word root (disciple) and the priority of maintaining
column7: not disrupting
column8: the loving relationship.  I've summarized this approach and discussed the downsides of spanking in the following chapter from my book on raising boys

column1: I love very short stories

column4: Suspicion
column5: Revenge
column6: All This and More in a New Collection of Amazing Short Stories-Each One Just 55 Words Long" edited by Steve Moss;   2) a second 55-word story book edited by Steve Moss;   3)"Flash Fiction: Very Short Stories" longer than the Micro Fictions selections
column7: but less abstract 4) Many of the Barnes and Noble short story book selections.

This is a curious book. To start with
column2: it is short. Without the Notes section
column3: it is about 220 pages. There is no index or photographs or illustrations. The text has the feel of a random selection of magazine articles thrown together. There is an attempt to hold the whole thing together with the author's own personal observations of rats in an alley in lower Manhattan
column4: but the author tends to spend more time discussing what he was wearing or drinking than about the actual rats in the alley. I am fairly certain that you could rearrange many of the chapters in virtually any order and the book would not significantly change. The writing style is occasionally humorous but for the most part seems like an attempt to be erudite rather than an actual success.  As to what you will actually learn about rats
column5: there is very little here. You will learn more by going to Wikipedia
column6: and the writing there is no worse. Many of his "facts" are prefaced by
column7: "According to one study..."
column8: "By one estimate..."
column9: "One rat expert theorizes...". This might not be too bad if the source of these "facts" were cited but they aren't so there is no way to verify any of the information provided. And when an author is making fairly outrageous claims such as that one-third of the world's food supply is eaten by rats
column10: the reader would like some support other than just the author's word. Also
column11: the author tells us early on that there are only about 400
column12: 000 rats in New York but then he interviews an "expert" that he admires who tells us that there are millions of rats living deep under the city who never come to the surface. Is there any support for this? Is it 400
column13: 000 or millions? And even when he gets his facts right he gets them wrong. For example
column14: the author writes about the rats link to the Black Death but fails to note that the Brown rat that is in the city is not the rat that carries plague and in fact
column15: probably can't carry plague. The rat of the Black Death was the Black Rat which is not the rat the author is writing about.  Which brings up the side trips on the journey. Almost anyone in New York who has something to do with rats is a potential target for a chapter. Many of these people are not the least bit interesting and the claims they make are unsupported by any evidence but the author simply reports them as fact. His writing fails to cover any subject in any depth. He writes a chapter about John DeLury
column16: for example
column17: who was the head of the sanitation worker's union in the 1970's with very little detail beyond what you would expect in a typical obituary. And then he ends the short chapter with excitement that a friend of a friend is a grandson of DeLury. Ho-hum. He tries to interview people who might remember so-and-so who had some remote link to rats years ago but the interviews go nowhere. A typical response he gets is
column18: "I didn't know him personally but I understand that people spoke highly of him." Excuse me? Why is this even worth writing down? Is the author that desperate to pad his book?  Overall the book does not educate the reader about rats
column19: does not provide much in the way of historical detail
column20: and barely entertains. I would not recommend that anyone waste their time on it.

column1: This is a post-modern waste. Full of catchy and titillating drivel that goes in circles until it feels like you
column2: not John Self
column3: are the one with the hangover. Might have made a good short story; instead we've got this bloated thing.  The reviewers who say this captures the spirit of the Reagan/Thatcher era read the blurb on the back cover if nothing else. There is nothing in this book that remotely resembles a depiction or criticism of 80s culture. The book isn't even about money (though Amis tries to make it so by inserting the word as much as possible

column1: In desperate need of a light read and curious about the multi-author approach used with this novel
column2: I dove into "Naked Came The Manatee" with anticipation of the fun and excitement typical of Elmore Leonard and Carl Hiassen writing.  The story unravels the mystery behind two heads
column3: both with a great similarity to Fidel Castro that are lost in transport from Florida to Cuba.  Each of the thirteen authors writes a chapter of the novel
column4: with Hiassen and Leonard attempting to pull the story together in the final chapters.  The characters are odd and criminally inept as most characters in Hiassen's and Leonard's writing but the story is underdeveloped and lacks the immediacy of a great crime mystery.  If you have nothing else to read and this book happens to be within reach give it a try. Don't expect much and you won't be disappointed

column1: I first picked up on the Anita Blake series a little over a year ago. I was absolutely enthralled. Not only was the main character witty
column2: intelligent
column3: and kick-butt
column4: but there was a memorable set of supporting characters to see her through. Who can forget Zerbrowski's antics (even in the worst of times) or the cold-hearted killing of everyone's favorite bounty hunter? After reading my share of the books and floating around to some of the other reviews here on Amazon
column5: I am left wondering the same thing many of the other fans are: what happened?  I just finished Narcissus in Chains. Normally when I finish a book
column6: I'm left with a sense of fulfillment
column7: like I've accomplished something. Unfortunately
column8: that was not the case. I've always found this series to capture me from the get-go
column9: but trying to convince myself to read this one was hard. Not only was the plot rather weak
column10: but Anita seemed to keep on debating the same situations over and over. Jean-Claude
column11: Richard
column12: Micah
column13: and even Asher seem to plague her thoughts. And although she will do anything to save a member of her pard
column14: or anyone else for that matter
column15: her focus always seemed to drift back to the boys. And did anyone else notice the repetitiveness in the writing? Hamilton used the exact same wording for certain feelings or actions throughout the book. Unlike the earlier part of the series
column16: the writing in Narcissus in Chains is less imaginative and less memorable. On top of it all
column17: come the end of the book
column18: we have this bad guy who I can't even remember where he came from in the first place!  My favorite part of the books has always been Anita's police work. I am honestly ten times more interested in her career than I am in her love life. I miss having a tight
column19: intense plot that flows
column20: instead of drifting around like some kid with a short attention span. And as pointed out in the book
column21: the charming Anita Blake we used to know and love really has become a monster. A literary disaster of a monster.  Although the reviews for Cerulean Sins are probably just as grim as the reviews for Narcissus in Chains
column22: I plan to go ahead and continue the series. I can't give up on something that has such great potential
column23: and from the sound of it
column24: this next one has a more recognizable plot. I can only hope. Unfortunately
column25: I believe that Obsidian Butterfly was probably the last of one of the best series and best characters ever created
