"It is now widely assumed that religion played a minimal role in forming America's Founding ideals.  America's Founders
column2: it is said
column3: consciously rejected religious principles and borrowed their best ideas about law and politics from the ancient Greeks and Romans in addition to Renaissance and Enlightenment philosophers.  This view is common throughout most history textbooks today.  Although Greek
column4: Roman
column5: Renaissance
column6: and Enlightenment sources were important
column7: their influence has been overemphasized
column8: while the influence of religion has been seriously understated."  This paragraph from the Foreword of Never Before in History sounds like a reasonable thesis and one for which I have great sympathy.  Unfortunately
column9: this book never quite lives up to its thesis due to a combination of poor scholarship and sloppy reasoning.  For example: -John Calvin was never the mayor of Geneva
column10: as the book asserts (p. 46) - he wasn't even a citizen of Geneva until shortly before his death.  -Slavery in the south could not have troubled the northern Puritans
column11: as is asserted on p. 119
column12: as letters are available in which the northern Puritans discussed which races made the best slaves.  -The authors
column13: throughout the first part of the book
column14: champion "consent of the governed" when discussing the colonies' break with England.  But when they reach the writing of the US Constitution
column15: however
column16: they claim that it was a "permanent bond that could only be broken by death."    -In order to prove the Puritan influence on the Founders
column17: the authors try to tie the major characters of the Revolutionary era to the Puritans through various tenuous connections
column18: e.g. Samuel Adams was a Puritan because he went to Harvard
column19: which was founded by Puritans.  This last point is
column20: I think
column21: the most egregious error of this book.  It flattens over a century of colonial history into a one-dimensional picture
column22: so that the authors can equate any one who believes in God in the 18th century with the Puritans of the 17th century.  Surely the Congregationalists
column23: Unitarians
column24: and Deists of the 18th century had little in common with their Puritan forbears of the 16th century.  Attending a college founded by Puritans over 100 years earlier hardly made one a Puritan.  If you are interested in the thesis that this book begins with
column25: a far better source is A Theological Interpretation of American History by C. Gregg Singer.  Like Amos and Gardiner
column26: Singer believes that we can identify Christian influences in the founding of our nation
column27: but we must look beyond the founders to the Puritans.  Writing over 20 years before NBIH
column28: Singer
column29: accurately describes the problems apparent in the later book:  "That the Jeffersonian democracy was founded on Christian principles and simply reflects the social implications of the Gospels is one of the most deadly
column30: and at the same time one of the most persistent errors of contemporary America.  The reference to God in the Declaration of Independence
column31: and the apparent submission to his will
column32: should not blind us to the tragic misuse of biblical ideas to convey Deistic principles for the realization of a society which would be essentially humanistic and anti-supernaturalistic in character." 	"Many sincere evangelicals are unwilling to accept this fact
column33: apparently in the fear that in so doing they are conceding too much ground to those who
column34: in our own day
column35: wish to carry this process of secularization to even further excesses than occurred in the early days of the Republic.  Their motives are most worthy
column36: but the ground they have chosen on which to defend the evangelical cause
column37: and the cause of a truly biblical conception of the American state
column38: is faulty.  They must choose higher ground and that higher ground is the Puritan conception of our destiny
column39: the Puritan Dream for America.  Puritanism did not lack for defenders and while their voices were stilled to a great degree during the excitement and full bloom of the Revolution
column40: they would still be heard
column41: and that Puritan heritage would rise again to give health and vigor to the new nation under the Constitution
column42: for in the Convention of 1787
column43: it would gain a hearing that it had been denied in that earlier assembly.  An evangelical strategy which overlooks the clear testimony of history in regard to the nature and purposes of Jeffersonian democracy in the interests of preserving the essential elements of a Christian patriotism is doing a great disservice both to the Gospel and to the very patriotism it is seeking to preserve."  (pp. 41-42)  Singer explains the difference:   "The Puritans held to a very different conception of liberty from that which is so prevalent in contemporary thought and governmental theory.  For the Puritan
column44: liberty was in no way associated with the doctrine of natural law and natural rights
column45: but found its origin and meaning in that covenant which God had made with his people.  Liberty was not a natural right
column46: but a God-given right and privilege to be zealously guarded from despots
column47: to be sure
column48: but also subject to precise Biblically-defined limits." (p. 17)  "The whole conception of government that would later be proclaimed by John Locke and others
column49: which placed the sovereignty in the hands of the people and which found the origin of government in a human compact was utterly unknown to the Puritans."  (p. 18)  These two very different ideas are simply flattened into one by Amos and Gardiner and labeled "Christian."  Although history does need to be somewhat "simplified" for children
column50: it should certainly not be simplified beyond usefulness.  This is what I think Amos and Gardiner have done
column51: to the detriment of our students.

column1: Somebody else here described the author
column2: Barrett Tillman
column3: as a "US Navy groupie."  Whoever wrote that hit the nail on the head.  This is a book aimed squarely at a nostalgic
column4: generally politically right-wing Americans who enjoy hearing stories of how brave their boys were
column5: how great their weapons were
column6: how great the odds were
column7: how great their sacrifice was
column8: and how sweet the victory was.  It is a true life adventure sotry for people whose concept of history is closely related to knowing unit histories and aircraft variants.  Scholarly
column9: insightful
column10: and deep
column11: it ain't.  Now
column12: don't get me wrong - the boys were brave (very much so) and the weapons were cool and so on and so forth.  And there is very much a place in the world (I guess) for a book that very conspicuously goes out of its way to name virtually every possible named American sailor and airman
column13: knowing full well that this could lead to a sale by the sailor or airman's family
column14: extended family
column15: and so forth.  Such people deserve this sort of book - they deserve our eternal honor
column16: respect
column17: and thanks.  However
column18: the Marianas Turkey Shoot / Battle of the Phillipine Sea deserves a more adult and balaced treatment.  It also deserves better writing than this 8th grade-level stuff.  The good news is that Barrett Tillman has taken a bunch of good detail and anecdotes
column19: mixed it in with a bunch of bravado and nonsense
column20: and has produced something that future historians can build upon.  The bad news is that those of us expecting a "Shattered Sword" or "Fire in the Sky" caliber analysis will have to wait until somebody picks up the mantle.  Oddities and absurdities:    - The book features a Rush-Limbaughesque intro by Steven Coonts where he rails about NAFTA and wonders who will build America's LSTs when the next World War 2 comes about since our manufacturing jobs have been shipped to China for low low WAL*MART prices.  The introduction is embarassing to read.  - One of the reviews
column21: by Henry Sakaida
column22: lauds the book for it's "balance and fairness."  I wonder if that guy even read the book.   There are maybe a dozen total pages that deal with the Japanese side of things
column23: and they are mostly general background.  Clearly
column24: Tillman has been surpassed elsewhere by writers who actually speak Japanese or could be bothered to collaborate with somebody who does
column25: as his bibliographical sources dealing with the Japanese side of things is shallow and out of date.  As i skipped a few pages here and there I could not swear to this 100%
column26: but I don't think Tillman interviewed a single - NOT ONE - Japanese associated with the battle.  - The book's seethes of jingoism.  Pilots on all sides over-estimated and over-claimed aerial victories ("kills").  When describing American over-claims
column27: Tillman not unreasonably excuses young and excited pilots for their overeagerness.  When descriving Japanese overclaims
column28: however
column29: the prose is full of sarcastic
column30: sneering quotation marks.  The contempt Tillman has for the Japanese (or at least
column31: the contept he portrays in order to play to the sensibilities of a certain demographic of book buyer) is obvious.  - In a giant aerial battle such as the Marianas Turkey Shoot
column32: the very least one expects from a serious history is a comparison of killed claims vs actual losses.  Mind-numbingly
column33: this is basically nowhere to be found in the book.  However
column34: there are literally dozens of paragraphs that go like this:  "Lt Joe B. Smith of Little Rock
column35: AR saw four Zekes and with his wingman
column36: Lt Robert F Jones of Missoula
column37: MT took three scalps in a space of five minutes while the last one scurried away into the cloud cover."  No attempt is made to verify such events
column38: link them to the faceless Japanese pilots
column39: or even
column40: for the most part
column41: provide good technical analysis of the air combat.  That said
column42: here and there Tillman has included interesting anecdotes
column43: stories
column44: and technical details that are a testament to his many years of research and experience.  Unfortunately
column45: a lot of it is also complete BS.  Besides the expected stuff that has filtered through from his interviews of veterans and their occasionally over-vivid memories
column46: there's some technical nonsense that Tillman has simply made up.  For example
column47: in describing dive bombing attacks on aircraft carriers
column48: he suggested that SBD pilots would aim to drop their bombs on the stern (as opposed to the center of the flight deck
column49: the normal preferred aim point) if they happened to see parked and fueled planes there.  This is all well and good in theroy - in practice
column50: this never happened and
column51: for all practical purposes
column52: never could happen.  It's simply an example of Tillman basically making something up that sounds technically plausible but actually simply does not reflect historical
column53: operational reality.  Should you buy this book?  It depends.  When I was 14 I ate these kind of books up (the one that comes to mind is "The Fighting Lady"
column54: a book about the USS Yorktown CV10 that I read when I was about 10) because I didn't know any better.  They helped me imagine that I was there and ignited an interest and a passion in the subject.  Then I grew up and my desire for insight and balance grew.  Therefore
column55: I personally found this book quite unsatisfying.  I think in general it's just very
column56: very average

column1: This book on the black market makes a case for going back to views popular in the 1960s.  In the 1960s
column2: the black market was populated with cold-war spies and gun running free-booters.  Since then
column3: the popular press has painted the black market as a drug running paradise.  Naylor tries to convince us this image is a lie.  The real black market criminals are capitalist executives in the military-industrial complex.  Defined in this manner
column4: 'Wages of Crime' becomes a traditional left wing vehicle for brow beating those unwilling to genuflect before Marxist-Leninist dogma.   This critique is not limited to attacks on the US political establishment.  At one point Naylor laments that Gorbachev's generation 'forgot its ideological roots'.  On another page
column5: Naylor describes the proletarian interests in South East Asia.  The reader won't find the standard pulp crime stories here
column6: which is a blessing.  Unfortunately
column7: the book relies on rhetorical flourish rather than statistics. Thus
column8: it simply substitutes one stereotype with a second.    The text was pulled from independent articles
column9: so the flow is sometimes uneven.  For example
column10: a chapter seeking to debunk the political might of heroin/cocaine dealers tries to convince the reader that drugs are of marginal economic importance.  He complains that the published estimates of drug dealer wealth are too high by perhaps a factor of 100.  In another chapter
column11: rich drug dealers engage in crimes with military-industrial complex.

column1: Tens of thousands of books are published every year: few of them sell more than a couple of thousand copies at best. Sometimes you come across a book from a "name" publisher and wonder why the manuscript wasn't tossed into the wastbasket. This is one of those books.    This book is filled with New Age nostrums. "Let's visit the cosmic sphere tht contains our neighborhood - the center of our visible universe." (By the way
column2: Leo Tolstoi visited this neighborhood in the 19th Century in his "The Kingdom of God is Within You.") More great advice from Primack and Abrams
column3: the husband-wife team that claims great new cosmological insights: "Movement becomes a mere idea. There is no visible way to detect it
column4: only the tricky conciousness of time passing." Here's another gem: "The Cosmic Las Vegas metaphor illustrates trhe random
column5: quantum nature of eternal inflation
column6: but it gives no sense of what the theory of eternal inflation could mean if it is true." Yeah. Sure.    Reciting every mawkish statement in this pretentious tome would take as much space as the book itself. As a final example
column7: how about "We represent  an age on Earth comparable to the age of cosmic inflation at the beginning of the universe: brief
column8: but about to set the pattern for the long-term future. . . . For our entire species
column9: today matters."    This New Age gruel is served up as a plea for scientific thinking. It is anything but. It is a feel-good tract on how special you are
column10: much like the character in the classic Saturday Night Live sketch.    Greater good could have been done by saving the trees sacrificed for the paper the nonsensical nostrums of Priamck and Abrams are printed on.  Jerr

column1: "Big Cotton" and US agricultural subsidies are big news in the world of trade. Yafa teases a promise to enlighten on this situation
column2: but fails to deliver.  Yafa knows there is a big and tangled picture here to illustrate
column3: but is unable to work out the world view and settles instead for a series of scenes in cotton's long history. The start of the industrial revolution in England
column4: the rise of Lowell
column5: MA
column6: the beginning of Levi Straus & Co are written as grand chapters containing some amusing anecdotes
column7: but sitting in isolation.  In the final chapters
column8: pesticides and genetically-modified cotton appear
column9: largely wrapped in a diatribe on the evils of both rather than any real analysis. Yafa has left out how the South changed from a resion of sharecroppers pre-WW II to industrial farming by the mid-50's.  Most disappointing are the final chapters on the current world trade. There is a complex story to be told here of US politics and farming as well as farming in Africa. Yafa misses most of this. The devil is in the details of most of this story. With few if any numbers and no detail of costs or pricing Yafa cannot capture this story. It does not lend itself to a journalistic approach
column10: although Yafa's refernces to stories in the Wall Street Journal suggest that the WSJ writers may have written a better piece on the subject than "Big Cotton".  Meanwhile
column11: Yafa purports to tell a tale worldwide in scope
column12: yet his "Big Cotton" is really a US story. After 300 pages of almost exclusively US tales we are told that China is the biggest current producer. Where did the Chinese industry come from? Or Pakistan's or India's?  If you are looking for the story of cotton
column13: keep looking - this is not the book

column1: In response to the overwhelming academic reaction to his first essay "The American Civil Religion
column2: Robert Bellah again addresses the creation, development, and subsequent destruction of the covenant" manifested in the American Civil Religion in his book
column3: The Broken Covenant.  By enumerating and expounding upon the "myths" of the American Civil Religion
column4: Bellah attempts to uncover the American self-understanding that has both created and corrupted the Covenant. The myth of origin reveals the basic self-conceptualization of America: a pristine wilderness
column5: a place of new beginnings for "the chosen" who reform the old covenant.  According to Bellah
column6: from a biblical as well as classical republican perspective
column7: America is a land of living myth with a covenant based on Calvinist teachings of common charity
column8: love
column9: individual dignity
column10: and responsibility through which the internal spiritual covenant meshes with the external political covenant to create public virtue. He believes that the American "covenant" legitimizes and gives purpose to the American identity. He compares his book to the lamentations of a prophet crying out in the wilderness
column11: trying to alert the population to societal corruption and impending doom while maintaining a hope for the future upon repentance. He argues that utilitarianism
column12: capitalism and science
column13: along with the "sins" of slavery and the treatment of the Native Americans
column14: have corrupted and destroyed this covenant
column15: leaving America empty of purpose. In violation of the covenant
column16: capitalistic self-interest motivated American society instead of republican virtue.  His solution espouses the creation of a new covenant that humbly recognizes the past and present flaws of America
column17: renews the traditions of the old covenant and provides moral and spiritual meaning for the technological and scientific dimensions of modern society.   Using mostly primary sources
column18: armed with a sociologist's understanding of American history and fueled by personal experience
column19: Bellah attempts to evaluate the American Civil Religion in the past
column20: present
column21: and future.  Though he realizes the current problem regarding the corrupted ideals of republicanism
column22: equality
column23: spirituality and religion
column24: his ideas for the resurgence of the American Civil Religion are vague and abstract. He proposes a state of constant revolution
column25: a continuous renewal of covenant through religious and spiritual rebirth that will fill the external political covenant of America with meaning.  Along with the restitution of the inward covenant
column26: Robert Bellah kowtows to the popular theories of the early 1970s
column27: such as communitarianism and socialist policies
column28: which have failed thus far in America.   Rather than a transcendent new order
column29: he espouses the call for reform common to the generation disillusioned by the Vietnam War and Watergate scandal; his book appears to be the result of a personal attempt to find meaning in a changing modern society.

column1: Recently I developed a fascination for Japanese horror movies. Some of the Japanese movies are really frightening to watch
column2: and leave a deep impact on your after watching it. Some of these movies include the Ringu(the Ring) series
column3: Ju-on(made as `the Grudge' in English starring Sarah Michelle Gellar)
column4: and also The Eye series. After watching all of the movies mentioned previously
column5: I thought I would give All Night Long (called `Ooru naito rongu' in Japanese) a try. Sadly
column6: I was not pleased with this one.  The first of the trilogy revolves around 3 guys
column7: who by coincidence
column8: witness the murder of a woman by a psychotic man who randomly kills her on the street. Strangely enough
column9: these 3 guys get together and become friends and decide to throw a party in order to forget the incident they were witnessed to. They decide to get dates for the party
column10: but in the end
column11: due to various incidents because of other people
column12: fail in doing so. Due to these incidents
column13: they decide to let their anger off and take revenge on these people.  The second story
column14: called `Atrocity'
column15: starts off with a high school boy who is spends his summer vacation by chatting on the computer
column16: and playing with a doll. He is bullied by a gang headed by a homosexual
column17: who develops an interest for the boy. As the boy does not feel the same way about the leader
column18: this leads to some disturbing consequences.   The third movie
column19: named `Final Atrocity'
column20: is considerably the most graphic of all three. This time
column21: the story consists of a young boy who works in a sleazy hotel
column22: where customers bring in their partners to have sex with
column23: and leave garbage lying around. The boy apparently likes collecting trash
column24: and starts collecting those of a woman living near the hotel
column25: who he is attracted to. He starts following her around and collecting everything that she throws
column26: to the point where he even starts eating rubbish that she leaves behind.  Katsuya Matsumura
column27: the director behind all three Nihilistic movies
column28: tries to portray the disturbing image of human nature in all three of the movies
column29: and succeeds to some extent. While the first movie was an average (I thought it would be really good considering they made so many sequels to it)
column30: the second and
column31: especially the third
column32: focus on too much graphic violence and abuse
column33: which just stalls the storyline of the movie
column34: not even progressing anywhere. The only high point of all these movies is the acting
column35: which is considerably good
column36: since you feel that the characters are at some point really insane. The eerie music also adds well to the background during some scenes. This is why I gave this a 2 star rating. The only reason I saw the whole series was because I was hoping that the next sequel would be better than its predecessor. After watching all the movies
column37: you don't feel scared; instead you are left with a feeling of disgust and revulsion towards them. In the end
column38: you wonder
column39: what the point of the whole story was in the first place.   So
column40: if you want to watch some really good Japanese horror
column41: consider the ones I mentioned in the beginning of the review. However
column42: if you like a lot of gore without any storyline
column43: give `All Night Long' a try

column1: I ordered this phone on 3/28/07. It shipped via FEDEX on 3/29/07 to my office with an indicated delivery of 3/2/07. The package sat on the FEDEX truck for three days before they attempted to deliver it at 8pm to an adjacent business and then left it without the package being signed for. column1: I have progressively become more and more disappointed with Rita Mae Brown's books in the past decade. Her early books were utterly magnificent; now

column3: utterly boring) themes -- Southern manners
column4: horse bloodlines
column5: and foxhunting. Blessedly
column6: "Whisker of Evil" was foxhunting-free

column8: and many of us have grace
column9: manners
column10: and respect for others -- and we don't take kindly to being told that only Virginians understand these things. That's just simply not true.  That said
column11: there were some delightful aspects of "Whisker of Evil" -- the mystery itself was great
column12: the animal characters were adorable as ever

column15: but she took it way too far and I found myself skipping pages. As well
column16: I almost threw the book across the room when I came across a line that stated in so many words that only Virginians have manners. This is a common theme of Ms. Brown's and it is quite frankly offensive. There is a big
column17: big world outside of Virginia -- Rita Mae Brown should know this
column18: she has lived in it -- but her books and characters have become so parochial
column19: insular and snobbish that it is an insult to those of us who do live elsewhere in that big world. I would have thought these kinds of statements were tongue-in-cheek if it wasn't such a recurring theme in so many of her books over the past decade. Enough already about Southern manners (a biased perception at best)

 Although Roizen and Oz have a great premise here for loosing weight what they have to present gets lost in the presentation.  The book is full of idiotic quips that are redundant, serve no purpose to the book, are a distraction to the overall message of the book and at times were rather degrading.  While the quips are at first funny, 30 pages into the book it gets to be rather tiredsome.  And the diagrams and cartoons in the book didn't add to it at all.  The diagrams belonged more in an elementary school science book than in a book whose target audience is suppose to be adults.  The cartoons, like the quips, just got tiresome.  I was inspired to go out and buy this book after seeing the YOU ON A DIET show on TV.  I honestly thought the docs had something useful here.  Unfortunately I was only able to make it half way through this book before having my fill" of it.  As the diet was in the last part of the book I didn't quite make it that far and at this point I just don't have the stomach to open this book again.    As I mentioned before I do believe that Roizen and Oz have a good premise here however I just found this book to be too full of silly foolishness to be taken seriously as a diet book.  I am glad to see that it has worked for others
column6: I just wish these two had presented their material better as I was totally ready to give their ideas a SERIOUS try - unfortunately I just don't think they were serious enough about their ideas for me to try them.  I don't recommend this book to any serious dieter.  If you want serious motivation
column7: a common sense plan and someone who will talk to you like the adult you are then I suggest any of Bob Green's books - a very enjoyable read from which I gained enough motivation to lose 50 pounds!!  Having reached a plateau that I am having a difficult time breaking I thought something new and different might be worth a shot.  You On A Diet was definitely not new or different

column1: **** - Four Stars
column2: and not two as shown above.   --Remarks on Colour-- is the last fruit of one of the greatest minds of the XXth century. It is a book that allows a most clear view of how intuitively brilliant Wittgenstein is; but in more than one sense
column3: it is disappointing. Above all because he writes it largely on the shoulders of Goethe's --Farbenlehre-- and Runge's observations
column4: without dedicating a single comment to him who has been increasingly disclosed as his mentor and master of youth: the unsurpassed creature of insight named Schopenhauer.  As a whole
column5: Wittgenstein's book can be considered a bundle of topic additions and observations to the Farbenlehre. As everything he wrote
column6: it is extremely sharp and illuminating
column7: indeed of inestimable value. However
column8: it lacks what Goethe's readers would be expecting to see: a personal position on those which were Goethe's main aims; firstly
column9: the critique of Newton's famous spectrum of colors: two centuries ago
column10: Goethe brilliantly challenged the Newtonian notion
column11: still held in utmost esteem in our days
column12: that white is composed by a melange of seven colors through a prism. Secondly
column13: an appreciation of Goethe's attempt to postulate what he intuited as the original phenomenon
column14: Urphaenomen
column15: without being able to explain why: colors complement each other qualitatively in pairs - the most important examples would be orange and blue; yellow and violet; and
column16: above all else
column17: green and red.  Wittgenstein is also unfair to Goethe: criticizes him for not having presented a finished theory (III
column18: 125) as if he had ambitioned that; whereas Goethe expressly states in his work that what he has to offer is but "Data zu einer Theorie der Farben". In fact
column19: to translate --Farbenlehre-- in any language as "Theory" of Colors would be a similar mistake. The gap between Goethe's objective observations and subjective self-awareness is bridged precisely by Schopenhauer's treatise of 1816
column20: --On Vision and Colors--
column21: an attempt to account for the subjective forms of colours; Wittgenstein does not mention it once.  Maybe one could
column22: very scholarly speaking
column23: call this a case of bad bibliographical review by a genius thinker. For --Remarks on Colour-- does bring the impression that Wittgenstein did not really know Schopenhauer's treatise at all. But this can only bring astonishment to the reader: the same astonishment that arises when one sees how unnoticed the book has slipped through almost 200 years; for example by Rudolf Steiner
column24: the brilliant thinker who prepared and commented the intents of Goethe in the present edition of the Farbenlehre (3 vols. Verlag Freies Geistesleben). In the case of Wittgenstein
column25: this is especially striking when one considers how much he dwelled with the philosopher's works as he prepared his earlier projects
column26: particularly as the Tractatus was written (a good account can be found at Bryan Magee's --Philosophy of Schopenhauer--
column27: 2nd. ed.). Had Wittgenstein read --On Vision and Colors--
column28: things would have been a lot different
column29: and maybe this entire book would have followed a completely alternate path
column30: since it would have to rise up to the task of judging the treatise of 1816. A sad instance of his neglect can be seen when
column31: at page III-26
column32: Wittgenstein makes comments which he does believe are quite decisive and original
column33: and which would be indeed
column34: had Schopenhauer not already explained why. Witty writes: "Blue and yellow
column35: as well as red and green
column36: seem to me to be opposites - but perhaps that is simply because I am used to seeing them at opposite points on the colour circle". It is something to be truly mourned that a man with such a marvelous intuitive grasp of this fact has missed the chance to meditate the theory that seeks to account for his perceptions. Because they bring no novelty to whomever has had the chance to read Schopenhauer's thoughts of why colors are qualitatively complementary.  At the end
column37: the general impression that remains is that
column38: theoretically
column39: Wittgenstein's comments about colors stand one step below Schopenhauer's treatise
column40: corroborating and indeed confirming it; exactly in the same way in which the --Tractatus-- stands one step below the --Fourfold Root of the Principle of Sufficient Reason--
column41: corroborating and confirming it; and
column42: likewise
column43: not mentioning it.  Schopenhauer's treatise has been for many years out of print in English. Shouldering and even surpassing the Farbenlehre
column44: it is perhaps the most important but
column45: at once
column46: the least read human study of the borderline where philosophy and physiology meet. Which is where Wittgenstein also stands with this little red book
column47: so acclaimed by his own fans

column1: This book provides a broad overview of some of the issues behind the Simplicity movement.  The author
column2: Cecile Andrews set up a number of Simplicity study circles near her home in the Northwest.  This book reveals some of the factors that led her to become interested in Simplicity as well as her ideas of how Simplicity study circles might work.  Much of the beginning of the book provides justification for adopting Simplicity.  Andrews enumerates problems such as hyper-consumption
column3: environmental degradation
column4: and personal isolation.  She also explores possible actions we could take to solve these problems
column5: such as consciously building community with other people and the earth
column6: finding ways to express our spirituality
column7: and restructuring our economic system to make it more environmentally and socially friendly. In the last part of the book
column8: she describes the idea of Simplicity study circles
column9: the benefits that might be gained from participating in one
column10: and how a study circle should operate.  She also provides a 10-week study plan based on the earlier material in the book.  Although I agree with the ideas in this book
column11: I found the book rather disappointing in content.  Much of the discussion is either so personal as to be hard to generalize
column12: or else a superficial summary of other more substantial texts.  For example
column13: Andrews frequently refers to findings of Juliet Schor; readers would have more material for discussion by reading Schor's works directly.  Some of Andrews' suggestions for addressing problems are rather inappropriate.  To draw attention to hyper-consumerism
column14: she suggests surreptitiously clothes-pinning tags with messages like "You don't really need this
column15: do you?" inside articles of clothing in shops.  While I'm all for trying to get people to become more aware of their needless purchases
column16: I don't think messing with the property of individual store owners is an acceptable way to go about the mission.  Her suggestions for reforming our economic system would be great in an ideal state
column17: but until we are run by a benevolent socialist dictator
column18: I don't think they can realistically be put into action.  It would be better to focus our efforts on goals that are conceivably achievable.  Overall
column19: while I found the topic of this book interesting
column20: I think there are numerous other books on the topic of Simplicity that are better implemented
column21: starting with Joe Dominguez and Vicki Robin's "Your Money or Your Life".  It's hard to tell from this book if Andrews can take credit for originating Simplicity study groups such as those run by the Northwest Earth Institute.  If so
column22: she certainly deserves credit for her efforts in that area
column23: but I don't think there's enough substantial material in this volume to use as background reading for an effective study group by itself.

column1: Heinlein is a great author.  When he sits back and tells a story
column2: he's one of the best.  Glory Road and Citizen of the Galaxy are wonderful
column3: and The Moon Is a Harsh Mistress should be on the shelf of any science fiction fan.  This
column4: however
column5: is an awful book.  It's not merely one of Heinlein's worst.  It's one of the worst books I've ever had the misfortune to read.  The problem isn't that there's no action
column6: although there isn't.  The problem is that there isn't anything of substance to replace it.  There's lots of sex
column7: but not in enough detail to be titilating.  There isn't a love story either; you can't have romance or sexual tension when your characters will sleep with anyone and everyone for any reason.  The book just rambles aimlessly until it ends.  Maybe Heinlein was trying for an examination of gender roles and sexual identity
column8: but if so he failed miserably.  The characters in this book aren't just from a different culture; they aren't people at all.  They're too flat.  If you want to think about such things
column9: ponder them on your own or read a different book.  I suggest Left Hand Of Darkness by Ursula Le Guin.  I Will Fear No Evil reads like an old man's rambling personal fantasies.  Someone must like it
column10: but I can't recommend it even to the most devoted Heinlein fans.  If you're tempted
column11: do yourself a favor and re-read Stranger In A Strange Land instead

column1: I had heard of Edgar Cayce before
column2: mainly because I shelved so many books by or about him in my years as a bookseller. It was only recently
column3: though
column4: as I was browsing through one of the Stranger than... books by the late Frank Edwards that I  came across a brief biography of Edgar Cayce and learned more about his mysterious diagnoses given while unconscious. I remembered that I had this book
column5: one of the Time-Life Collector's Library of the Unknown reprints
column6: on my shelf and so I dug in.   For the most part
column7: the prose was easy to read and written in a straightforward
column8: familiar style
column9: so that I felt like I was seeing the events of Cayce's life as they happened. The book begins like a normal biography
column10: discussing early romances
column11: jobs
column12: family incidents
column13: etc.
column14: with very little to indicate how strange Mr. Cayce's life would become. Around 1/3 of the way through the book
column15: we discover
column16: along with young Edgar
column17: that he can memorize written materials just by sleeping on them. He also discovers that he has miraculous powers to diagnose illnesses and prescribe cures for people he has never met
column18: all while unconscious. (In his waking life
column19: Mr. Cayce was very modestly educated
column20: and was as surprised as anyone at the ideas and language that came from his unconscious form.) The way that this section of the book reads
column21: you would imagine that Cayce's cures were always successful and that skeptics were fools.  The book begins to drag after the second half
column22: though
column23: for a variety of reasons. First
column24: Cayce could never actually put his powers to any real end. Every attempt to establish a multidisciplinary hospital to implement and research his unconscious revelations
column25: as was his dream
column26: came to an unsuccessful conclusion. This is fairly anticlimactic and does not make for a very "heroic" story. Second
column27: one of his benefactors
column28: a man quite interested in matters occult
column29: began to ask Cayce more arcane questions
column30: and so the revelations began to drift into
column31: to me
column32: less interesting areas-the typical new age stuff about Atlantis
column33: reincarnation
column34: soul mates
column35: etc. Finally
column36: it became more apparent to me
column37: based on the later
column38: more thoroughly documented cases
column39: that Cayce's "miraculous" cures might not have been as amazing as they seemed in the earlier chapters; the earlier cures seemed more amazing simply because the way in which they were recorded and related was more "oh gosh" and less stringent. (In other words
column40: as he gets older and more jaded
column41: even his cures seem less special and miraculous. Maybe this was the writer's intention.)    The conclusion of the book was
column42: for me
column43: the worst part. It is divided into two appendix-like sections. In the first section
column44: the author tries to systematically describe Cayce's philosophy. Boring. Too much like the Ascended Master stuff that I find hard to swallow. Maybe it is true. Maybe not. Whenever I read this stuff
column45: I just get the feeling that I am listening to some pedantic
column46: New England minister lecturing on matters that were expressed much more interestingly 2
column47: 000 years ago by Hindus and Buddhists. The second section in the conclusion recounts six case studies from the Cayce files
column48: and these are interesting only for those who want to see how difficult to understand Cayce's medical diagnoses could be
column49: due to the odd structure of his language and the outdated medical terminology.  It was a quick read
column50: except for those two concluding sections
column51: so if you are at all interested
column52: I highly recommend reading it. As for what it means
column53: though
column54: I really have no clue. And I don't plan on re-reading it to find out
column55: though the pretty Time-Life book will remain on my shelf as decoration.

So once again the special effects department has broken their backs carrying this movie. Without a strong plotline or interesting characters

column6: but just an impressive light show. It seems as if George Lucas figured that if the technology that he has now is light years ahead of what he had twenty five years ago
column7: then the audience won't need anything else. The special effects in the three 'prequel' movies was so inconsistent with the older films that they should have been released as a completely different story alltogether.  And finally we get to Yoda. A puppet that can bounce around and defy gravity with a lightsaber
column8: but still needs a cane to walk. In the older films
column9: Empire Strikes Back for example
column10: Yoda was balancing on Luke's feet during his handstand. When Luke lost his balance and fell over
column11: wouldn't Yoda be able to just use the force and gently float to the ground instead of tumbling to the ground out of control with him? Is that because of lack of special effects technology back then
column12: or just Yoda was getting too old to use the force anymore? Just a little food for thought. I'll let you decide.  So once again the only plus in this film is the impressive visual effects. If your expecting more however then George Lucas will once again let you down

column1: As Stephen Schwartz has said before

column3: a representative of the American academic Left and a Lebanese-born academic who teaches at California State University/Stanislaus
column4: attempts in this small volume to explain to his ideological constituency such matters as the history of Wahhabism
column5: the relationship of the Saudi state to Al-Qaeda
column6: the current crisis of the Saudi kingdom

It means detailing grotesque inhumanities but blaming them all on the United States and Israel
column10: as well as on colonial rulers past and the fantastical specter of "Orientalism."  AbuKhalil does not disappoint. He derides Western authors (this one included)
column11: who have exposed the bloody past of Wahhabi Islam

column13: in my view). He recapitulates the Wahhabi historical time line but adds nothing to what is already known
column14: except for occasional flings into the typical Western academic idiom
column15: aimed at softening or explaining away Wahhabi extremism. Thus
column16: the main Wahhabi-Saudi theologian in the second half of the twentieth century
column17: Ibn Baz
column18: "may not have been as principled in his hostility to Jews and Christians as his earlier edicts may have led us to believe." To identify the anti-Jewish and anti-Christian bigotry of Ibn Baz with a "principled" position might seem sycophantic but it fits the prevailing ethos on American campuses.  The author presents himself as the revealer of authentic Saudi reality
column19: but his portrait of the country differs from that described by the most acute critics of the kingdom only in its ideological vocabulary. After enumerating the usual atrocities and undeniable instabilities
column20: AbuKhalil has no solution to offer aside from condemning
column21: yes
column22: Washington neoconservatives for provoking "fanatical and radical forces" in Iraq
column23: and thereby threatening the Saudi state.  The litany is tediously familiar: America was wrong to enable Saudi tyranny
column24: just as it is wrong to try to end it. The Battle for Saudi Arabia is not of use to those hoping to learn about Saudi Arabia. Its only value is to provide insight into current leftist intellectual gymnastics.

column1: The 2.0 GB SanDisk Cruzer Micro flash drive looked like a good deal when I saw it on display at Office Depot.  It was roomy enough for all of my data and configuration files
column2: was rated for USB 2.0
column3: and was reasonably priced.  My first choice would have been an larger version of the 1.0 GB Iomega I use at work
column4: but
column5: alas
column6: such wasn't available.  Unfortunately
column7: I waited too long to put the SanDisk through its paces
column8: or I would have tried to get a refund.  As many others have remarked
column9: it is horribly slow.  While backing up my roughly 10
column10: 000 files
column11: I found that it was taking about a second per file -- longer for the big ones.  This translated to around four hours to complete the whole operation.  Bulk deletes take just as long to carry out.  Using my Beyond Compare file synchronization software to *read* the SanDisk and compare its contents to what was on my hard drive went reasonably fast -- until
column12: for no obvious reason
column13: it hung on one particular Word document this evening.  I couldn't even get my Windows XP machine to shut down without yanking the SanDisk from its slot:  the usual "safely remove hardware" operation wouldn't work.  After three attempts to read the same file
column14: and three reboots
column15: I tried to delete it from Windows Explorer -- and this operation hung too.  Finally I was able to do the deletion from the DOS prompt.  Just like 1985!  I then recopied the file
column16: and now Beyond Compare can finish its work without a hitch.  But can I trust the SanDisk to deliver up my precious files when I really need them?  I dunno ....  So
column17: it's back to the drawing board.  Maybe by now Iomega has come out with that 2.0 GB model.  As for the SanDisk
column18: I'm reminded of that painful adage:  you get what you pay for.  Ugh

Buyers beware!  I have never written or posted a consumer rating in my life.  I am so disappointed with Vonage's overall customer service; I feel that I have no choice but to warn others.  Vonage in its own words does not guarantee the quality of its service. Vonage customers will experience: (1) dropped calls
column2: (2) garbled communications
column3: and (3) a non-responsive and dishonest customer service department.  The reason Vonage does not guarantee performance is because it knows that it cannot.  My first mistake was in believing the Vonage help desk
column4: during my initial
column5: "30 Day Money Back Guarantee Period
column6: when they told me my issues were due to line quality and not Vonage.  Since then, I have spent three months with Vonage and my High Speed Internet Service Provider's technicians attempting to make this service work. All speed tests indicate my ISP lines are fine.  I had a High Speed Internet Technician visit my house last week only to tell me everything checks out.  All this said, my Vonage phone has never worked worse.  I made a call today and the recipient could not even discern whom I was.  When I finally threw in the towel and decided that Vonage was not for me, I was hit with a $39.99 service charge upon cancellation plus the cost of the phone, despite a documented lack of performance from day one.    Vonage's performance is substandard by any measure.  Closely look at all other options before bringing Vonage into your life and definitely terminate all agreements within your first 14 days to avoid the inevitable early termination fees.  Make sure you read the below clauses in Vonage's Terms of Service agreement before you agree to anything.  A Vonage Customer Service Manager, Mike, sited these disclaimers when I told him that I was not satisfied with the service: (1)	No Warranties on Service
column7: section 4, paragraph 4;  (2)	Return of Device
column8: section 2, paragraph 10; (3)	Termination Fee
column9: section 3, paragraph 6; and (4)	Money Back Guarantee; Limitations and Conditions
column10: section 3, paragraph 7.  When I switched to Vonage, I was simply looking for a reliable telephone service and a company that stands behind its product and supports its customers.  Vonage's lack of line reliability and poor customer service has motivated me to document my experience.  I had to call Vonage Customer Service on my old fashion landline because the voice quality on my Vonage phone was so poor that I would not be able to have a conversation.  After waiting for 20 minutes to talk to the Service Manager, Mike, I was told that I was contractually bound because I did not terminate my agreement within the first 30 days.  At this moment I thought of the stereotypical shady used car transaction.  I was lured to buy Vonage because of the promises of great service and all the free bells and whistles that only internet calling can provide."  Instead I received a lemon
column11: a phone that was unreliable and a company that did not stand behind its product.  While Vonage may get my $39.99 termination fee and the cost of the Vonage phone
column12: I do not feel that I can just lay down about Vonage's failure to perform.  I feel compelled to (1) warn others about Vonage and hopefully save them the aggravation that I have experienced and  (2) Hit Vonage where it hurts
column13: in the economic pocket book.  I am terminating my service as soon as possible.

column1: This book was published in 1995 (so of course was written in about 1993-94) so its information is very out of date. Since that time technology has introduced the BMD bone density scan
column2: and the pharmaceutical industry has developed and promoted the use of bisphosphonates such as Fosamax and Evista. These two developments alone have rendered this book totally out of date and therefore not useful
column3: in my opinion. Also
column4: the information is not evidence-based
column5: most of his recommendations are based on anecdotal and observed results
column6: rather than on scientific studies. What he has to say is interesting
column7: sometimes even fascinating
column8: but is it accurate? For example
column9: his recommendations on caffeine are based on the result of an "experiment" of giving three cups of coffee to five women. I don't consider that evidence-based medical protocol.  A vastly better source of information is The Myth of Osteoporosis
column10: by Gillian Sanson
column11: published in 2003. Her book is exhaustively researched
column12: she cites medical and research studies involving hundreds and thousands of subjects
column13: she covers the newest technologies and medications. The only thing missing from her book (because it was published a few years ago) is the very latest information about the potential dangers of Fosamax and the class-action lawsuits about the death of bone in the jaw that has caused people to have their jaws removed.  She provides excellent suggestions for improving bone health
column14: including exercise
column15: dietary changes
column16: supplements
column17: and other ways to beat osteoporosis. She doesn't say that osteoporosis is a myth
column18: she just debunks some of the myths surrounding this condition. I highly recommend this book over the Gaby book

column1: This could have been a valuable reference.  The front cover lists 39 names

They emotionally vent against the psychoanalytic view that includes binding mothers and detached fathers.  They grouse over psychoanalytic notions of homosexuality as a "pathological defensive
column14: phobic retreat from castration fears" and renounce employing a "directive/suggestive" approach to treatment.  The authors cite at least one well-known activist by only calling him a "contemporary author."    While Chapter 8
column15: Controversies in theory notes that "Freud regarded sexual orientation as largely constitutional" (p223)
column16: the reader must flip to the "Notes" section (p263) to read
column17: "Freud termed homosexuality a perversion
column18: because he considered only heterosexual genital intercourse to be the 'normal' sexual organization.  In the Freudian lexicon
column19: perversions are pregenital fixations caused either by constitution (an overabundance of one or another component drive) or conflict."    The authors have an agenda to discredit theory and call it "expansion" and "transformation" hoping to convert readers to their own way of thinking.  In perusing earlier reviews of this book
column20: they appear somewhat successful.  You might ask
column21: are the authors simply preaching to the choir
column22: or have these reviewers not thought through the material in order to provide credible opinion?  As far as this book being required reading for a doctoral class in Psychodynamic Theory
column23: as one reviewer states
column24: I would hope that expectations of a critical read would accompany such a requirement.  Some of the reviewers appear to be thirsting for knowledge...any knowledge concerning psychoanalytic theory and will drink from the first cup available
column25: without question.   The book's authors
column26: by using vague phases such as "In many cases" to denote Freudian thought to which they disagree
column27: offer no examples to support their attack and leave the reader guessing.  Basic Books is a reputable publisher.  The reader deserves better.  I bought this book but returned it after a selective skimming through its contents.  Finding that the mission of transformation is a failure

column1: I first read A WALKER IN THE CITY as an adolescent
column2: and the book impressed me
column3: in that mysterious way that things that we know "should" impress us can do.  I re-read WALKER as an adult and
column4: by modern standards
column5: I think that it is overrated.  It is long and rambling and self-indulgent.  By rights
column6: A WALKER IN THE CITY should have resonated for me
column7: since my own father had grown up in Brownsville
column8: exactly the same neighborhood that author Alfred Kazin describes
column9: and at virtually the same time.  Yet I found little about Brownsville in this dreary memoir; it simply explores the rather maudlin sentiments of the young Kazin. Swifty Lazar
column10: the late literary agent who was renowned for representing men of letters
column11: as opposed to being a man of letters himself
column12: had offered a far more compelling description of life in that same Brownsville in his own memoir.  No
column13: WALKER only is about Kazin and his adolescent imagination
column14: his theories about those who lived in places other than Brownsville (to wit
column15: "the city") and about his personal (and intensely idiosynchratic
column16: if not peculiar) yearnings.  There are points in which he uses Yiddish without offering a translation
column17: and even a section in which he lapses into high-school French
column18: again with no translation. His use of language often seems strained and self-conscious
column19: such as using the word "plash" as--I think--a synonym for "splash."  Insofar as much of the book had been printed in contemporary magazines as essays
column20: the format here has cobbled together several essays into a memoir. In consequence
column21: this memoir could have used better editing
column22: since things that are fully explained on their first mention do not need the identical explanations further into the book; such styling would be reasonable in a series of magazine pieces
column23: but not in a volume offered as a cohesive work.  I cannot help wondering whether A WALKER IN THE CITY
column24: first published in 1946
column25: would be as enthusiastically received if it first saw print today. It strikes me as the literary equivalent of the Emperor's new clothes

column5: to the Swing of the Dirty Boogie
column6: to the Rockabilly of the Comeback Special
column7: and the superb tribute to sun records.  But

column9: and are repeated endlessly. Such as in the song "Bad Bad Girl in a Bad Bad World".   For example here is a small snippet out of the song mentioned before:   She's a bad bad girl in a bad bad world A bad bad girl in a bad bad world It's not her fault she's a bad bad world It's so sad it's a sad sad world She's a bad bad girl in a bad bad world A bad bad girl in a bad bad world It's not her fault she's a bad bad world She's a bad bad
column10: bad bad
column11: bad bad
column12: bad bad girl  What garbage! By the end of the little chorus you just want to give the CD a toss.  Many of his songs are riddled with the disjointed tempo changes found in punk music. Setzer has been able to do this subtly in the past without calling attention to it
column13: but there are a few songs on here that just sound confused. Definately not a Setzer trait.   There has never been a Setzer song that I absolutely cannot stand

column15: which until now he has never fallen short of. This CD is still far better than 95% of the crap that is being released in today's market.  To summarize I would encourage Setzer to get beyond this CD

it requires effort from owners.  Bought this to help control our Sheltie's barking behavior.  When we first tried it
column2: he would stop and look around to see where the sound was coming from.  We noticed that this alone wouldn't stop his bark and required us to work with him by using voice commands like 'No' or 'Quiet'. This  meant alot of time and patience working with him and my kids didn't help very much.  They have a tendency to push the button and not do the commands.  So now the dog thinks that the sound comes from the birds that he likes to bark at...lots of re-training to do here.  Well the dog hasn't stopped barking and obeying yet
column3: but we haven't been as good at working with him either.  My next purchase will probably be a Citronella Collar..I'm opposed to the shock treatment from shock collars as this seems cruel and can teach some dogs to be mean.  Better still maybe a good book on dog training is in order.   My oldest daughter used this when walking the dog around the neighborhood and found that it did stop some of the neighbor's dogs from barking or at least got their attention.  My question now is could this possibly stop or delay a dog attack??...at least long enough to get away or somehow protect yourself.   Not sure I would want to risk trying this though but it might be worth taking on walks..just in case.

At least Mr. and Mrs. Darcy are out of the country for the duration of the novel and are spared the humiliation of making an appearance in such a second-rate piece of work.

column1: There are just two rules when you create a thriller with a pretty lead: 1) The lead (the delectable Ashley Judd) had better show some skin. 2) Thou shalt not be boring.  Twisted utterly fails on both counts.  Basically
column2: Judd is Jessica Shepard
column3: a messed up cop who specializes in hunting serial killers.  She's fond of bedding men she meets at late night bars
column4: because she's self-destructive.  Only Jessica looks fabulous all the time
column5: even when she's been on a bender (which is apparently every night).  How she maintains her good looks without stinking up the place is just another part of cinema magic.  Jessica is mentored by John Mills (Samuel L. Jackson).  For a second there I thought Jackson was going to play an understated version of his usual maniacal self.  I was wrong.  Things take a turn for the strange after Jessica discovers that every man she sleeps with is murdered.  And she keeps having these weird blackouts every night.  The victims wash up on the shore the next day with a single cigarette burn on their hand.  Poor Jessica is haunted by her parents' murder/suicide and wonders...since her father went on a mass-murdering spree before he killed himself
column6: could she too have the "serial killer gene"?  Jessica is paired with Mike Delmarco (Andy Garcia)
column7: an Italian goomba who is alternately creepy
column8: lecherous
column9: and like everyone else in this ridiculous movie
column10: wants to get into her pants.  Mike follows her around an awful lot...could HE be the killer?  Or maybe it's the ex-boyfriend cop
column11: Jimmy Schmidt (Mark Pellegrino).  Or maybe it's...actually
column12: I figured it out in the first ten minutes.  Being something of a true crime fan
column13: and having read a bit on the subject
column14: this entire premise is absurd. You don't wake up one day and become a serial killer; if anyone actually got a good look at the life of a serial killer
column15: it screams DANGER from day one.  Pretty Jessica has none of those problems in her past
column16: except for a vague "suppressed rage" that manifests itself in kinky sex and kicking people in the face.  Her cherubic face shows no signs of hardship
column17: and neither does the rest of her. Although the script wants us to believe she's a haggard cop
column18: the camera is only too happy to zoom in on her rear end.  Not once
column19: but twice.  And it's not a naked rear end either.  So we have a gorgeous female cop who sleeps around
column20: yet there are very few bedroom scenes.  We have a serial killer plot that is connected by red herrings (Who is that lady across the street?  Why does Jessica fiddle with a cigarette but never light it?).  On one hand
column21: the cops are strictly by the book; they make a big deal out of the fact that Jessica kicks a serial killer in the face.  On the other hand
column22: nobody pulls Jessica off the case when she's a prime suspect
column23: nor watch her home when the serial killer is obviously following her around.   Neither sleazy or highbrow
column24: gritty or moralistic
column25: Twisted is so boring
column26: it gets bored with itself

column1: People who enjoy this book seem to characterize it as an original work of sci-fi/fantasy and a thought-provoking exploration of insanity
column2: which interests me very much.  However
column3: I found this book to be neither original nor an adequate account of someone's "descent" into or recovery from madness.  The premise is intriguing enough as the novel begins
column4: gradually revealing the story of an amnesiac/schizophrenic patient being admitted to a psych ward
column5: who turns out to be a professor at Cambridge.  Immediately
column6: the reader is thrown into 50 pages or so of stream of conciousness ramblings that were quite frankly difficult to trudge through.  This put a bad taste in my mouth
column7: possibly tainting the rest of the book for me.  The remainder really wasn't terribly interesting; I found Lessing's writing style to be excruciatingly boring and lacking any sort of insight.  Other reviews of this book tend to fall to the extremes of loving it or hating it; I guess that means I hated it.  So maybe I just didn't "get" it...personally
column8: I don't think there was anything to "get".

column1: Goldwater's disastorous 1964 Presidential campaign is the vehicle for telling the book's real story: the rise of the ultra-conservative movement in American politics in the sixties. It is undoubtedly an important story
column2: and one that Perlstein has researched considerably. However
column3: Perlstein's work is undone not by his findings
column4: or his damaging portrayal of the burgeoning right-wing movement -- I concur with him on these points -- but by very lazy presentation. Perlstein has obvioulsy drunk deep at the David Halberstam well. He can rattle off an anecdote
column5: but he is dreadfully prolix. The book is at least two hundred pages too long. No reader opening a book on sixties politics needs an eight-hundred word summary of Kubrick's Dr. Strangelove. Perlstein has also made a mess in organising his material; he leaps back and forth
column6: from person to person
column7: without ever stitching the requisite parts together. One moment Henry Cabot Lodge looks to be the certain favourite for the 1964 Republican nomination
column8: and we are treated to fifteen pages on the organisation of his campaign; later we are told
column9: almost as an aside
column10: that he has withdrawn from the race
column11: and Perlstein never explains why. Sam Tannehaus's 'Whittaker Chambers' is a much more assured analysis of the growth of anti-communist hysteria in the fifties and sixites
column12: and is considerably shorter and better crafted than Perlstein's book. A more thorough editor and an author more intent on telling the story carefully and well would have made 'Before the Storm' a much better book than it is

column5: avoid this book and look to John Chernoff's African Rhythm and  African Sensibility

column1: The author spends the entire introduction claiming how Muay Thai is the most effective self defense martial art out there.  But in doing so
column2: he turns a condescending attitude towards every other martial art.  He says that Hollywood makes 120 pound women believe that they can defend themselves with "windmill" punches.  Yet the author
column3: himself
column4: is the one who succumbs to the myths surrounding other martial arts.  So he believes other martial arts like Tae Kwon Do and Karate are useless because all they teach is flashy movie moves.  But this only goes to show that the author has absolutely no idea what the other arts teach authentically.  TKD and Karate do not emphasize 720 degree jump spinning monkey kicks to protect oneself.  In fact
column5: the first thing you learn in a TKD or Karate school is to punch and to defend yourself against a punch.  Just because all these Hollywood and Hong Kong movies utilise flashy moves does not mean that other martial arts teach that this is the way to defend yourself in a real fight.    Kickboxing has its limitations just like any other art.  If you get grabbed and thrown by a judoka
column6: what are you going to do?  Does kickboxing teach you how to fight from the ground?  If you're a Brazilian jiu-jitsu artist and you get into a fight with more than one opponent
column7: what are you going to do?  Slap on a submission hold while a guy comes up from behind you and stabs you?  Instead of proclaiming that he and his style of fighting is the best
column8: the author should really think about what he's saying.  Style bashing (as it is commonly known in the martial arts circles) only shows ignorance.  I haven't seen this author defend himself in a street fight or fight in a no holds barred tournament.  But I have seen Tae Kwon Do and Karate guys defend themselves perfectly in a real life street fight against multiple opponents and in one on one situations.  And there was a K1 (Kickboxing) competition in which Muay Thai fighters fought against Kyokushin Karate opponents.  Guess who won?  That's right
column9: Karate.  And these are gripes I have just about the Introduction!  The rest of the book was pretty useless.  He says that the book is about conditioning and techniques.  The conditioning section only consists of pictures of a guy lifting weights.    ...all I can say is that it was completely useless.  No effort to tell how much weight to use
column10: how many sets
column11: how many reps
column12: and workout schedules?  I know how to lift a dumbbell and do a bench press.  I don't need this guy's book to show me a picture of it.  And the techniques section was very basic.  If you have even seen a kickboxing competition
column13: you will probably learn more from just watching it than from the useless (!@$&) this guy shows.    This book is a definite waste of money written by an egotistical ignoramus who wants to sound like he is the best fighter in the world and knows everything about fighting.  Yet he can't even put together a simple book on anything useful about kickboxing.  Don't buy unless you really want to waste your money.  There are much better books on Muay Thai on Amazon.  Actually
column14: any other book on Mauy Thai on Amazon is better than this one.    I was duped into buying this based on all the other favorable reviews on Amazon.  But now I know that they must have been left by the author or his friends.  Or by people who have never trained seriously in Muay Thai or any other martial art.  A much better book is Complete Kickboxing by Martina Sprague and Keith Linvingston

column1: Uhh....am I missing something here or what?  The person who is the Reincarnation of Edgar Cayce was BORN in 1998!!!  Last time I checked
column2: that is how reincarnation works!  That's what is meant by "will enter in '98".  No other logical reasoning exists.  If this guy is arguing that since he realized who he was in 1998 that that must mean he is the incarnation of Cayce sounds more like him trying to fit a square peg in a round hole and trying to convince the reader he really is the circular peg
column3: just with added corners!!   Gimme a Break! And for the other reviewers who found the structural philosophy of the book interesting there are many more out there that do a much better job introducing you to the edgar cayce story and material than this one.  A few that are off the top of my head includes "Our Origin and Destiny"

column7: many good books about All this Without an ego-trip from the author.   You Know
column8: I could claim the same thing and be just as convincing about being Cayce than this guy.  But
column9: Oh wait! I forgot! I'm NOT SEVEN years old now am I?  Unfortunately
column10: we will all have to wait around twenty years or longer for the genuine article to be old enough to have a chance to write the NON-Fiction version of this book idea! Just type in "Edgar Cayce" in the amazon search bar and find a real book on the subject

column12: you are left high  and dry figuring out gender
column13: declinations

That did solve our problem and left us convinced that "new and improved" does not necessarily  provide a better learning experience.  Somewhat IRRITATING:  Ms Kershuls's choice of vocabulary seems to assume that 1. you wish to visit lots of relatives  (not an uncle
column17: niece
column18: grandson
column19: cousin
column20: grandparent
column21: or daughter  is forgotten in the family tree)

column27: "music"

column36: rather than "single catch words". ------------------  Our final test

column1: Since I do a lot of driving
column2: I bought this as an audio book to hopefully ease the pain of sitting in traffic. This book is more irritating than traffic jams.          The heroine in the book
column3: if you can call her that
column4: was not at all likable. She was arrogant and in my opinion
column5: her arrogance made her foolish. For example
column6: when a police detective she was working with telephoned her on her cell and asked her where she was she responded with a smart remark rather than tell him where she was. Why? Simply because she did not personally like him.  Moments later she was knocked out and taken captive. Later when she woke up she bemoaned the fact that no one knew where she was. Dumb! And this is only one example of her stupidity. Ironically
column7: earlier in the book she referred to this police detective and his partner as tweedle-dee and tweedle-dum. Later
column8: this same policeman saved her life
column9: but she still was unappreciative and belittled him even when it was pointed out to her that the man saved her life.       The "heroine" also had a Canadian boyfriend who pretended he was a cowboy throughout the entire book. I thought maybe the author had just seen "Pillow Talk" with Rock Hudson pretending to be Rex Stetson while she was writing this book. It was bad.       The "heroine" had been separated from her husband for years but failed to obtain a divorce. She seems to have a hard time taking care of unfinished business and she constantly complains about everything.      The author bores the reader with long
column10: drawn out descriptions to the point the reader or listener is screaming
column11: "Okay
column12: I get it! It's hot outside!" If that weren't bad enough
column13: readers or listeners of this book are subjected to lectures on how we evolved from apes and endangered turtles. If I wanted to read about endangered turtles I would go to the non-fiction section. To add insult to injury
column14: the big mystery in the book
column15: the disappearance of an entire family
column16: turned out to be a complete non-mystery.       I was determined to listen to the whole thing but finally
column17: on the last half of the tape
column18: after enduring another political lecture
column19: I could take it no more. I took the tape out and threw the entire thing in the trash.          I have read thousands of books and I've listened to probably more than 60 audio books.  This was the absolute worse of the lot.  If you want to read or listen to a good forensic mystery
column20: stick with Patricia Cornwell and her Dr. Kay Scarpetta series. Cornwell's books are worth reading!

column1: While I loved the first two of Doss' "Shaman" series
column2: this one was a big disappointment. The author seemed more infatuated with his hero
column3: Charlie Moon
column4: whom he presents as a sort of Native American Jimmy Stewart
column5: than interested in constructing an efficient plot. There are an endless number of jokes about "the big Ute's" voracious appetite for fried foods
column6: his impressive masculine physique
column7: and his total bafflement over the behavior of the opposite sex. In fact
column8: Doss' depiction of women was one of the most irritating things about this book: They all (with the exception of Daisy
column9: the shaman) seem to belong more in a comic book than in a novel for grown-ups. Every last one of them has "tiny
column10: delicate hands
column11: a small foot
column12: crimson nails
column13:
and has no thought in her head other than how to land Charlie Moon (why they would want to is the only mystery in the book). I had been very impressed with Doss' handling of the mystical in his previous novels, but this one is so choked with cliches that I quit two thirds of the way through. And the shaman of the title, a vibrant character, gets little attention in this one. So if you want a well-paced mystery with touches of poetry in the writing and well-developed characters, go to Tony Hillerman

 So, poor Brooke Shields felt unhappy? So what? Is she unaware of the billions of people on this planet who live desparate lives of real poverty, who watch their children die of preventable diseases or starvation? Is she unaware of all the babies who die from malnutrition and malaria every year? And all she can do is sit in her mansion and feel sorry for herself. Of all the times in one's life, the time you are needed most is when you are a mother who has just had a baby, yet still she couldn't feel her own baby's love for her. How pathetic. I think she'd have soon changed her tune had she been marooned on a desert island after a plane crash, and she realised she could die any moment. People get 'depressed' because they spend too much time thinking, and thinking about THEMSELVES. Don't these pathetic people have anything better to do with their lives? Think of all the suffering she could prevent if she used her fame and money to do so.  She should read Stop thinking and start living"

column1: I bought this stereo because of its relatively small size and stylish appearance and because it had aux inputs for me to hook up my mp3 player to it.    The first unit I received would not turn on at all.  I contacted Philips' tech support
column2: and their solution was for me to send the brand new defective stereo back to them at my expense.  Fortunately
column3: Amazon has a very nice return policy
column4: and I sent it back to them instead.  Amazon was also very nice in sending a replacement right away without waiting until they received the defective unit.  The replacement stereo arrived in short order
column5: and I was immediately disappointed in the sound quality
column6: which didn't seem as good as the 15 year old cassette player boombox that I was replacing.  After listening to the stereo for a few days and comparing it to a Sony CMT-NE3 bookshelf stereo that I own
column7: here are my thoughts.  1. The FM reception is not as good as the CMT-NE3.  Both units have a thin wire type of antenna
column8: and both wires are about the same length.  The Philips stereo
column9: however
column10: would hiss and crackle as I moved around the room - my body interfered with the reception.  This did not happen with the Sony stereo.  2. The sound quality is not as good as the CMT-NE3.  Playing the same song side-by-side on the two stereos
column11: I found that the Philips stereo had a flat
column12: tinny sound when compared to the CMT-NE3.  The Sony system had a much fuller and richer sound quality.  Also
column13: there seemed to be significant distortion in the high-frequencies on the Philips stereo
column14: making "S" sounds sound more like "H" sounds.  I also noticed an occasional crackle of distortion in the overall sound
column15: possibly due to a bad connector on the aux input.  3. The ergonomics of the Philips stereo are not so good.  For one thing
column16: the stereo will easily tip over forwards if accidentally bumped.  If that happens
column17: the CD can get wedged in the CD tray and it becomes almost impossible to remove.  The electronically actuated CD door is much more likely to break than a passive mechanical door like the top-loading CMT-NE3.  The volume goes up to 31 or so
column18: but 5 is about as loud as you would need it for regular listening.  This means that there are only 4 quieter volume levels
column19: which is rather limiting.  Finally
column20: the stereo is a bit bigger than I was expecting (though I could have looked more closely at the specs when buying it).  I am in the process of returning this stereo
column21: and I will try to find a Sony system instead.  Unfortunately
column22: Amazon no longer sells the CMT-NE3
column23: which I bought just about a year ago.  I don't understand why electronics manufacturers feel the need to churn their product lines so rapidly.  Is there really that much innovation in bookshelf stereos?  The only difference between the Sony I bought last year and one I bought in 1989 is the ability to play MP3 CDs.
